content:
Posted: April 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								this game is so far, very nice. graphics are pretty good and controls, though a little bit strange at first (switching between mouse and crosshair controls mid battle because you ran out of 1 type of heals and need to use another can sometimes be fatal), eventually become familiar and you get the hang of what it is you're supposed to do...some things which may or may not be to your taste:-build mode and adventure mode are at the point of goodness where it's almost better to start with one of those and learn how to play rather than learn in story mode-combat with swords seems a bit pointless in almost every situation after you obtain guns, which is fair enough considering they're guns but it'd be nice for there to be a point to these higher tiers of swords and if it is gun-orientated then guns need more tiers. so yeah, using guns is much easier on you and your med packs, just remember to have bullets...-speaking of combat, there's not really much to it, if you use swords you walk in and click like mad until stuff is dead and normally it's you who dies first. theres no blocking or evasion (yet??) so you take every hit, your only chance not to get hit is to hide behind a tree and use guns to kill them while they run into it-for a rpg, apart from quests it has very few traits that one would expect to find in a rpg-i, personally, have found almost no point in actually gathering resources to make things. you can mine and collect stuff yes, but not to make things, only to sell it to npcs so you can buy the thing you were supposed to and save yourself a huge amount of time. however, if mining and collecting is something you enjoy get yourself a nice shovel and dig til your hearts content-if you do choose to do the storyline quests then prepare to spend upwards of 10 minutes running between campsites when you get a quest where you cant fast travel (or you lose the quest)-jumping feels a little bit slow to start, you press the key to jump and it takes a second to actually commence jumping because of crouching. pffft realismlil' bit extra:-i know its completely unrealistic but i think the jetpack should be able to fly me around forever. to hell with realism.-if rpg is one of the ways this game is going, stats, skills and levels may be something to consider??theres a hell of a lot to this game so far and i definitely think it has potential, i haven't yet experienced everything (i played build mode, got a jetpack and just flew around a bit then played some story) but most of what i have has been enjoyable and completely recommendable.not much else to say really, it's pretty simple, if you like sandbox, open world, crafting and understand the phrase "early access" then this game is awesome, it does a very good job of being pretty much what its tags say it is. though if rpg is what you desire most, then lower your expectations a little bit.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 9, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is really amazing, the depth is there but you are not required to get into it.  As fun as any survival game but without the repetitive zombie theme, instead you get a nice change with the sci-fi theme that brings crazy scenery, plants, bugs and even a somewhat scary enemy.  jEven at the early stage of alpha this game is currently in there is so much to do, once you figure out how to do something you will quickly be finding more and more to do and before you know it you have played for 6 hours.  You might think you would have gotten alot done in that time, well not likely the map in this game.....its enormous.  But for good reason, there is a creation system in the game that allows you to create; like actually "create" your own vehicles.  You get the basic guts and mechanical stuff, then you get to completely design the body, style, gun placement, how many wheels etc etc.  The creation doesnt just apply to vehicles and aircrafts but you also get the option to completely create your own sword, shield and gun designs.  Now you might think that leads to overpowered stupid looking junk that everyone will be using, wrong the creation system requires you to gather the materials you build with and it will take some trial and error before you really get what you want.  Its simple yet still very detailed when you want it to be, granted there is a short learning curve but those who would enjoy the game will have no problem with that.After watching some videos I recently came to realize there is a glider backpack and a grappling hook in the game that you can aquire somehow.  So far I have only played the story mode and that has taken quite a bit of time to learn and make a small amount of progress through.  So I have not had the thril of jumping off high mountain tops and gliding around this enormous map, or using the grappling hook to climb insane mountains.  I have only seen video of the aircrafts you can potentially design and I cannot wait to design my own.  The game is every bit worth the $24.99 price tag and to think its only in the alpha stages.  I cannot wait to see what else they add to this game, I unfortunately do not have the internet access to use the multiplayer feature but exploring this massive world with all the options they give you would be alot of fun with a friend or two.  I look forward to the future of this game and hopefully you will take the time to immerse yourself and enjoy the adventure that is available in Planet Explorers.

content:

Early Access Review
								Yeah I'll recommend the game, but it has many flaws that need to be worked out (like the fish, you can look at my screenshots and find one of a massive fish that is just out of the water stareing into my soul with eyes like headlights). It is loaded with cool and interesting things and even has some of my favorite things for a game to have. Like the giant monsters and the creation system, but the whole thing has such a steap learning curve it took me the best of 1 hour to make a crappy looking gun. The UI is weird and wonky at alot of points, but it works. The wildlife is extensive and is filled to the brim with wonderous creatures, but if they weren't as insanly hard to kill in story mode it would be better. EX: At one point for one of the objectives I had to investagate ruins of a past race, but massive bird creatures had taken a liking to the place and the would agro if I approched. So i took up archery and tried long range combat the started chasing me and they did massive damage so I died at least 20 times before I was able to cheese them to death. Also their are game breaking glitches like one I experianced I had to follow a character to a little pond area and their were enemys their and for some reason after I killed them he walked to his spot or close to it at least and he stopped moving. The quest never updated and he never did anything either. THIS HAPPENED EVERY TIME I TRYED TO REVERT TO A SAVE. So I had to restart but I mean the game is still in development I can't bash it to hard. The build mode is great but no ceatures spawn but you so its kind of boring. As far as I know you can't put a build world into an adventure mode so it spawns things but it would be awsome if you could this would be a great sandbox game. Kind of like minecraft but more my style of minecraft no creepers just giant murderous desert titans or robots or what ever they are I don't care the are cool as hell.I saw this game on green light years ago and downloaded the free version and oh my god so many glitches ranging from spawning in the sky and falling to your death to walking strait and then *Poof*AAAAAAHHHHHHHHH! right on down to the bottom of the universe it's self. So be thankfull that doesn't happen as much any more. So all its an ok game one to try out for a wile test out everything and see if you like it. Get the game on sale I bought it for full price, I dont really care but its not really worth $20 yet so wait for the full game and then make a full desision. Also please take liberties on the grammer I'm super tired.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2015
Early Access Review
								+++Developers seem genuinely interested in this game, despite some misfortune+++One of the sandbox with most freedom out there. Instead of downloading mods to get that decorative item you want, it's pretty straightforward to build it yourself with the in game creator. The complexity of the things you can build is pretty big.+++Brings something new to the table of the sandbox genre+++There is a story and a purpose!++The game is thought out and presents a meaningful and fair challenge.++Supports and encourages the modding community+Effort was put into graphics and animations and they look very good.-There are a few bugs-- game development is pretty slow (at least lately)---Some quests are boring and meaningless. The usual MMORPG quests, fedex quests, kill x enemies quests, escort quests.-A part of the community simply cannot hear any form of criticism. Make a suggestion at your own peril.-Needs a more explanatory tutorial. Took me a while to grasp the full potential of the crafting UI.-Combat needs more fluidity Worth the 23 Euros it's at. There's enough content to justify an non sale buy.

content:
Posted: August 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								I have played mostly the story mode, using the building functionality to weave in a little creativity, but I have yet to play this a la Minecraft. But I really, really like the game! The story is interesting, the world is immersive, and it's just plain cool. It's a very well done game. However, it's by all means still in Beta.My complaints:-Some of the missions require walking back and forth across the (very large) map, with fast traveling not an option when you have a follower. I dislike that, it's a waste of time. Enabling followers to fast travel with you would fix this, and I'm confident they'll do that before the final version.-The storyline gets implayable at a certain point. I hit a wall where a bug disallowed the game from recognizing one action as complete, and it couldn't progress the story. Obviously, these will be handled before a full release, so it's not fair to say the game is bad when it's simply (and admittedly) incomplete, but I thought it was nonetheless worth mentioning in my review.-Gathering resources to go through stuff you use in regular gameplay gets a little tedious. You can buy resources from certain NPCs, but the quantities available are small and the prices high. Building your own stuff is a nice part of the game, but gathering resources for an hour just to restock on bullets is annoying. Again, I expect they may improve this before the final release.My praises:-I really like the way combat is done, the way you can focus on it or not. There's a fair amount of combat to be done, but I just made automatic turrets, carry them in my inventory, and let them take care of whatever it is while I just keep clear. That way, combat for me is just making sure I've got enough turrets and ammo in my inventory for whatever I expect to fight.-The RPG and the sandbox elements work together really nicely.-The opening quests do a good job explaining how the game works. It did take me a minute to figure out what buttons to press, but once I got that down the explanations were helpful without being annoying.All in all, I think this game will be one of my favorites once it's done. The RPG gameplay seems to only be 60% done, whereas the builder gameplay seems to be 95% up and running. So depending on your gameplay preferences, you may prefer to wait it out until it's a little more complete. I personally chose to put it aside and plan to revisit it when it's complete, since I was more focused on the RPG gameplay, but I definitely recommend it either way.

content:

Early Access Review
								Now I've had the game for a while, I will write another review.Good:Infinite worldsLots of biomesLots of cool and different animalsGIANT ROBOTSA cool sense of explorationYou can make helicopters, cars, planes, boats, 100% customization of basically all items (even your own decals and stuff) Alien camps that you can invadeFriendly camps where you can buy materials and tools if you can't find themThe crafting system is pretty big and lots of parts to makeConstant updatesBad:Cutting down trees is annoying. You have to stand in the exact right place to be able to cut it, no matter how big it is it just dissapears into your inventory when your done and you keep on clipping inside of it like it's not even thereCombat is sloppy. You might as well be cutting onions.It is hard to see above the water when swimmingMining could be a bit betterGathering plants can be quite hard, you have to stand in the right place to get itQuite a few random glitches (crashes, flying for no reason etc.)Overall it is a really good game but could do with a bit of a polish, and the updates should be more focused on fixing bugs and improving things that are already there instead of adding more features into the game. I would definately recommend this game. 8/10 ( update from my previous 7/10)

content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								Surprisingly advanced for an Early Release. The story line is believable, voice acted, and complex. The world (I've only seen the first 2 areas of 7 I'm guessting), is massive, varied, and not without dangers. No, you won't get chewed up by any hostile mob, but when starting out you'll have to run. and mine, and do the quests. Later you'll be able to get on your self-built motorbike, and *try* to outrun a dangerous enemy you found deep in the forst. Will you be able to dodge the trees? Will he? After many many disappointments in its genre, I'm fully willing to say that this is a massive success in the in the Voxel / Survival / Crafting / Single player game, even well beyond anything else out there. My only negative is the ingame music, which sounds like children's lullabies to my ears... But it's easy enough to mute it through the settings (which are completely implemented), and run VLC in the background. Average performance usage of system while running Planet Explorers AND a 720P movie in VLC:CPU 38%RAM usage around 5 GB of 16GB. Nvidia GTX 760, no cooling (not even a fan). Resolution 1920x1080 on main screen running Planet ExplorersResolution 1280x720 on second monitor, playing the Terra Nova Series on 720p. --------------I recommend this game for children, especially those of all ages. This is absolutely playable for children in multiplayer with their parents, and it would be a great experience for them.You can build, and you can dig to find oreyou can do quests to find out more.Sneak around to see beautiful creaturesand learn what could become of own features. ----FANTASTIC GAME!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								TLDR; Recommended, glad I purchased it.It's really addictive. Check the other reviews and, even on the bad ones, notice how many HOURS people log playing this game! I'm ONLY at 13 hours.It reminds me a bit of Uninhabited Planet Survive[en.wikipedia.org] which was a fun show. If you liked the show you'll probably like the game, although I'm certain they have totally unrelated origins.I like exploring, building, and sometimes even following the story.The difficulty isn't very linear, which isn't a bad thing. In the real world you can walk into a forest and attack a rabbit or a bear side by side, but.. which one is more difficult? That's what happens here, too. And smaller isn't always less of a challenge either, likewise some big guys are pushovers. Could make it harder, actually.I haven't had much luck with Online play, though. It works sort-of, but my latency was measured in minutes so it wasn't really playable. Could be just me, but hey, it's a product in development.Solo play is rock solid, the graphics are awesome. There's tons to build and do already. While the game is solid and hasn't crashed on me, as other reviewers point out, it has some bugs. You may never experience them, but they're in there.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								This has got to be the best early access title I've ever seen... granted I haven't played a lot of them but I've certainly had my eye on quite a few ;). I'm VERY anxious to see what comes next. As for what we have now:PROYou can build anything in the *integrated* 3D modelling software and export it directly into your game. ANYTHING. Want a sword shaped like a hockey stick? Go for it. A motorcycle that looks like a giant taco? No problem. How about 50+ foot tall mech that seats three, flies, manuevers in three dimensions, and carries enough firepower to single-handedly liberate a small nation? Check out my screenshots... ;)Hundreds of building and crafting materials to use and mix together with a robust system that is phenomenally easy to use. Example: I burned through my gold pick and I'm a mile away from a repair machine and half as far underground. I open up my crafting window and select gold pick and the mats window tells me I need steel so I click on that right in the window.  Seems I have an abundance of mats for that so I make my steel and then I see up top that steel can be used for, among many things, gold picks. Click gold pick, click build, DONE. Easy.Story Mode. I've been mostly playing in Adventure Mode so I can't honestly speak to Story Mode a whole lot but I'll say  this about it: It doesn't suck! There are so many other games that wind up with devs scrapping most of the details on their story just to rush content... Not these guys and to me that shows integrity, something otherwise lacking in a lot of other titles.I have no cons, as it's still in developpment, so only positive criticism. I have a few suggestions, I know that a lot of devs read these reviews, and I despise digging through forums and creating more accounts everywhere just to post in a single thread somewhere so...Suggestions1st person. I know after reading around that you had it working at one point. This really needs a fix, mining in tight spaces with any kind of precision is impossible when your backside occupies the entire screen.Armor Dyes. I can paint anything I build any colour I want regardless of shape or size but not my armor? I like the models just fine and, quite frankly, custom armor is probably the one thing I have no interest in modding but there really should be an option to dye it. Maybe have a colour picker or something pop up in the crafting window when you click to build and if you choose to change the colour it tallies up the required pigments for you before finalizing?Weapon placement. I made a seriously bad♥♥♥♥♥gauntlet/katar with claws half as long as a man but to my horror the whole thing sticks straight up into the air behind my dude's head. Maybe if the creator had a new tab with a basic human shaped model we could specify wear a weapon should be worn (back, hip, etc.) and in what orientation, sort of like the same way we already can do with parts while building.Weapon pairing! I equip a sword and shield, no problem. I switch to my laser rifle, still no problem. Both are hotkeyed for ease but the moment I switch back to my sword I now have to go digging through my inventory to find my shield 'cause it missed the memo that it was business time. How about a pop-up menu for single handed gear that would allow the user to pair or un-pair the item with other one handed gear? Dual wield pistols, sword and axe, sword and board, etc, all with a single click once paired.More precise painting. The way paint bleeds from one surface inot another is actually pretty frustrating.Craftable solar power. Have I just not found it yet? I play in Adventure Mode mostly and I have yet to see it, yet there's a solar charger sitting outside a tent at the beginning of Story Mode. I wanna build one of those specifically!PAUSE in menu during single player. I don't think this one needs explanation but I'll throw this in here: It sucks if you have to leave your desk for a bit, or use the creator to tweak some stuff, and come back to find your toon starving.Like I said, no cons just suggestions. I could come up with more if I really put the time and thought into it but as it stands I have a craving for tacos now that must be appeased. This game is already well on it's way to being ace and I love it so far, keep up the great work, and for the potential buyer if you're into building games and the like then YES this is worth it :)

content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								It was only a matter of time that indie games start to shine.The tools are out there, they only need a little passion to make something happen.Planet Explorers developers have a real passion for creating something special.I've played so many beta games, I'm actually shocked at the level at which this game plays in alpha!Very playable, challenging, and enjoyable even in alpha stage.Best of all linux support, which runs beautifully!This is one of those games other company need to take a good look to.Quality first. Take time to make something you are passionate about and people will buy it!Bottom line, should you buy this game?The answer is a resounding YES!Even at full price and alpha stage, BUY THIS GAME!You will waste hours of your life! lolIndie developers need your support, and this team has earned it ten fold!Thank you Pathea!

								This is a pretty damn solid alpha.The graphics, top.  The weird freaky looking animals where you can't tell which is its head or it's butt that can beat the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of you? A+ Combat, holy♥♥♥♥♥♥prepare your♥♥♥♥♥♥because giant birds will hunt you across the map and kill you with some scary ice beam.  Not to mention, robots and giant aliens with oversized clubs.  Don't want to fight things? That's okay because you can just make a pickaxe and dig yourself into a mountain. This game has a lot of potential and I believe that they are going to follow through and have a very diverse game where you don't have to follow a set of rules or quests.  You can do whatever you want, whatever is suited for you.  This game type is a multiplayer/co-op must and I've had a lot of fun messing around this beautiful world with friends.

content:
Posted: August 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								I recently purchased this game when it was on sale for $15.  I feel it was worth that.  I have completed the story line for as far as it goes once, and logged most of the rest of my hours on the Adventure mode.  I tried the multi player for just a couple of hours.Pros:It's a beautiful game.  I really enjoy the look of the world.I like the basic crafting.  It's easy to find what you want in your recipes, and the resources are automatically selected if you have them, or indicated if you don't.I like the potential of the ISO creation tool. But as I will mention below it has drawbacks.I love the rope gun.I love the jet pack.I love the glider.I love being able to create a settlement.I like being able to recruit villagers to participate in my base.I like the farming.I like the resource gathering.Cons:The ISO creation tool was to difficult for me to figure out.  (the good news is there are sites available to download other peoples creations, and many of those are just beautiful)Weapons and monsters aren't well balanced.  Early weapons are nearly useless, ISO created weapons are too devastating.  Vehicles run out power/become damaged too quickly.  It's usually easier to just use your jet pack and glider than to bother pulling out a vehicle to get where you are going.Vehicle weapons are too weak.  It's quicker to just get out and kill the monster with your rifle, than to try blasting it with your vehicle cannons.There is a lack of sentient creature aggression.  Aliens attack if you run into them, but the never attack your base.  Animals will attack.  But they aren't a challenge.  The toughest thing is looting all the corpses that litter the field before they disappear.Settlement mechanics are still pretty sparce.  I am looking forward to those being fleshed out  in the future.There are a lack of building machines for tunneling, leveling, and raising land.  It's all done with a pick and a shovel.  I am looking forward to heavy equipment to speed up the beautification of my base.You can't replace natural earth that is removed.  So if you are trying to make a level spot for your garden and you accidentally hit the wrong spot, there is no way to fix it short of loading a previous save.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								Ignore my steam time, been playing this since kickstarter and loved it. Loved the sandbox world, ability to build what you want and more importantly import the creations of others (since my abilities to make things are very limited and never pretty). The developers stuck with the game and listened to what people wanted, building in multiplayer functions and a lot more. The development steps were also good, taking their time, not rushing to finish the game, but to ensure it works (meaning a few reworkings of the base engine and complete rebuilds), only opening up small parts of the map to start with, therefore giving early adopters new areas to explore as opposed to just new abilities (and boring replays). Great game, great development (the way kickstarter and greenlight should work).

content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								I never post reviews unless I find something special. This is the game I've been looking for over the last couple of years.  Best described: It's like Tereria / Darkout but only in 3 dimentions, with vehicles and weapons that you design and build yourself.  I love the mining mechanic and the user friendly crafting system.  I love that its not a badly rendered block world like Minecraft or Terarria. I love the free building and the creation system to create your own weapons, buildings & vehicles and turrets.  Even more shocking is that this game is still in alpha!  I've seen completed games that are far worse and bug ridden. I cant wait to try this out on multiplayer.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								I've now played more than 40 hours  in story mode, and I like it. A lot. I've just about came to the end of the missions, all that's left is some more monorail track building. That said, it has some problems, so this is mostly a list of things that need to be improved. MiningThis suffers from total confusion, because there is one rule: 3rd person perspective doesn't work with interiors. period. So what really needs to be done here is to implement a first-person view, this would fix that. Pathfinding AIThe NPCs are often jittering around, get stuck on trees or other obstacles, making mission where you have to lead somebody somewhere a chore. Scripted MissionsSometimes you've done something which you shouldn't have, like killed some monster before you get the mission, And then one of the "kill 0/3" monsters is missing. Or you killed the queen of the hive which you were only supposed to distract. What works in these cases is to save and reload, but then all three will reappear, and you need to kill all of them again. UIOn big screens, it's barely readable. There's need for a variable font-size.ColoniesThere are NPCs which can do mining or gathering, but it only works when they're your followers. It should really be possible to assign them this Job in the colonies. Also, it would be nice if it were possible to move around machines/beds in colonies, or remove and replace them without all the colonists loosing their status as colonists.VehiclesI've got difficulties steering them, probably due to some mouse/keyboard confusion on my part. A first-person view might fix this as well. Weight and ISOThere seems to be the problem that everything you create gets incredibly heavy; since everything is supposed to be "full metal" instead of being profiles and tubes. So you easily end up with 20 ton Jeeps. Not sure whether this can be fixed. On the other hand, I've never seen anything like it. I can create everything, from swords and guns to cars, boats and aeroplanes. Wow!CrashesIt does this often, mostly after fast-travel or loading a game (which both seem to use the same logic). But that's a known problem, related to memory consumption and apparently bugs in the Unity-Engine. So you can definitely expect improvements in the future. To sum up: This is around 40 hours of gameplay already, in story mode, and while some things feel weird or are unbalanced, it's definitely playable. Recommended.

content:
Posted: May 7, 2014
Early Access Review
								It took a minute to figure out what i was doing, but once i got the hang of it i couldnt stop playing.  Im a console kind of guy so I have been using an xbox 360 controller in conjunction with my laptop keyboard and track pad.  It needs a little more refinement and the controls will be very nice.  They are acceptable at the moment, very playable, and pretty much the only way to go for a laptop in my opinion.   Im managing to get 80fps consistently, with a small lag to about 50 randomly.  it doesnt effect the game play in the slightest, and if i lock in my fps at 60 its non-existent.  I have an i7-4800 and a gtx880m, i have played for an hour and a half straight and not a single problem.  The only thing the description of the game really needs to say is, "In what other game can you walk past a large flying animal attacking a dinosaur?"  I love this game!!!

content:
Posted: June 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								Having problems chopping down trees and getting flowers? It's right click. Yup. Yarp's guide was to subtle for me and it took me a total of 20 minutes to figure how to chop down a tree so I'm gonna tell you all. RIGHT CLICK. Anyway, the trailer is good, but this game is pretty rough. It's not worth the 25$, more like 10. I'd wait a lot longer as its a really new game. Not even the character customization is completed yet! The way to save a world needs to be turned into a user friendly menu. The build mode is annoying, I think that should be removed and put the building into normal gameplay, not a mode. The ISO maker, which allows you to create your own items is amazing. But the waypoint thing for the map is glitchy, it doesn't put the waypoint where your mouse is. I'd say I'd recommend it, but only if you are going to wait a year, mostly because major updates are months apart.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 9, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is really amazing, the depth is there but you are not required to get into it.  As fun as any survival game but without the repetitive zombie theme, instead you get a nice change with the sci-fi theme that brings crazy scenery, plants, bugs and even a somewhat scary enemy.  jEven at the early stage of alpha this game is currently in there is so much to do, once you figure out how to do something you will quickly be finding more and more to do and before you know it you have played for 6 hours.  You might think you would have gotten alot done in that time, well not likely the map in this game.....its enormous.  But for good reason, there is a creation system in the game that allows you to create; like actually "create" your own vehicles.  You get the basic guts and mechanical stuff, then you get to completely design the body, style, gun placement, how many wheels etc etc.  The creation doesnt just apply to vehicles and aircrafts but you also get the option to completely create your own sword, shield and gun designs.  Now you might think that leads to overpowered stupid looking junk that everyone will be using, wrong the creation system requires you to gather the materials you build with and it will take some trial and error before you really get what you want.  Its simple yet still very detailed when you want it to be, granted there is a short learning curve but those who would enjoy the game will have no problem with that.After watching some videos I recently came to realize there is a glider backpack and a grappling hook in the game that you can aquire somehow.  So far I have only played the story mode and that has taken quite a bit of time to learn and make a small amount of progress through.  So I have not had the thril of jumping off high mountain tops and gliding around this enormous map, or using the grappling hook to climb insane mountains.  I have only seen video of the aircrafts you can potentially design and I cannot wait to design my own.  The game is every bit worth the $24.99 price tag and to think its only in the alpha stages.  I cannot wait to see what else they add to this game, I unfortunately do not have the internet access to use the multiplayer feature but exploring this massive world with all the options they give you would be alot of fun with a friend or two.  I look forward to the future of this game and hopefully you will take the time to immerse yourself and enjoy the adventure that is available in Planet Explorers.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
Early Access Review
								(40 hours into a0.82) I was very very surprised at how much I liked this game and I look forward to it reaching full release at some point. Compared to my 50 hours of time put into Starbound (100 hours into Terraria), I think PE has a lot more going for it. The only clear negatives right now would be an out-of-memory CTD every 40-80 minutes of playtime, and the obvious, sudden "work in progress" placeholders for the story mode missions about 30-40 hours into the game (but suggests maybe another 10-40 hours of story mode at least). Other rough spots include game balancing and some issues w/ colony (micro)management and crafting/block placement.Those kinda pale in comparison to the sense of awe inspired by exploring the (story mode) landscape though. The graphics tend to be a bit cartoony but not much more so than Starbound/Terraria (but in 3D), but the landscape and views can be pretty breathtaking, and (spoiler alert) you can eventually buy/craft a jetpack and a glider, and along w/ a rope gun which gets some use, it reminds me a lot of the awesome feels coming out of Just Cause 2's parachute and grappling hook. The first time I crafted a simple flyer sled put an easy grin on my face too, and I had the odd but welcome reminder of how I felt when I enchanted some uber gear back in Daggerfall and Morrowind to do silly awesome things in a game, or the rush I felt realizing I could fly the jumbo jets in San Andreas.The game has an MMO-inspired mission progression and exploration/open world feel to it, with action gameplay that feels like Minecraft or Terraria/Starbound, married to gathering/crafting partly inspired by Minecraft, with an object-modeling/crafting system that feels both relatively powerful for a game while also being a bit limited in terms of a 3D modeler (even a partly voxel-based modeler). Most of your time will probably be spent exploring the breadth of the oft-times breathtaking landscape in story mode, and some of your time digging out ores (after finding deposits using your trusty ground-penetrating scanner). Story mode also has pretty nicely-written NPC dialogue that fits the graphical style of the game, scifi-ey with just enough cartoon feel to make it feel kinda epic w/o being too serious.Other (good) comparisons I could think of: Spore's exploration gameplay. Mining/gathering in the game isn't too bad either, but I'm not that into that kind of play, and tunneling isn't too satisfying b/c of the slower animation (but you get multiple resource units per swing). There's also no need-based survival-type management, aside from keeping your inventory stocked w/ hp and stamina consumables and ammo/repair mats, but this is similar to Terraria and Starbound which are still nice games without having Wayward or Don't Starve's emphasis on survival.Enough tangents though, PE is a fun game, as long as you can forgive the CTDs and current balancing issues w/ some of the alien creatures you have to fight from time to time (oh yeah, minimal flashbacks to Monster Hunter, at least seeing the size of some of those beasts, but don't get me wrong, combat is fairly straightforward in PE). I'm still starting out in adventure mode, so I don't know if PE's story mode strengths carry over, but my initial impression is that landscape/map generation could probably use some work.BTW, the map is pretty big, as in it take a while to hoof it from place to place even in one biome. There's Fast Travel to landmarks, but you also eventually get the ability to build cars, boats, or flying vehicles if you like (even making them into gun platforms), or as I said up top, you could jetpack into the sky then switch to glider to take to the skies (plus rope gun if you want to scale mountains w/o burning (camp-rechargeable but also craftable) battery).

content:
Posted: April 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								I am so addicted to this game.  The graphics are wonderful, the sounds and music are amazing.  The gameplay is something totally new.  You crashland on a dinosaur inhabited planet in the story, single player version.  Slowly you gather resources like plants, wood recipes for the replicator and meat... meat is your first currency.  Slowly you find other crashed people who have quests and further recipes.  This is a totally new concept of a survival game, an rpg... a shooter and a sandbox game.  Oh, and I haven't made anything yet but there's a built in 3D program that will apparently allow you to build anything you want.  No more just square voxel based pieces, now there's anything you can imagine.  I am so stoked, I can't wait to see them finish this game and to see what's next.  Game on, you have me hooked :)

content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								I have been playing this game since it hit Steam and have really loved it (for the most part) alpha bugs and all.  I love to gather resources, I love to build and I love to explore.  The game is perfect for those things.The down side is that the game is constantly changing.  That's what happens with an Alpha game that is being made as you play it.  None of the changes so far have made me want to quit playing though.  I do want to slap the developers from time to time, but the annoyance never lasts.  They are very good at fixing things that make players crazy.  If you are in the mood to gather and build, if you are able to handle random changes over time, this game is one you want to play.

On the down side, it's kinda slow going and a bit daunting sometimes. Plus combat is kinda wonky at times and your weapons don't get real good until much much much later in the game. But overall it's a pretty wonderful and beautiful game that I enjoy playing.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								Planet Explorers is setting out to be a game that really brings the word "sandbox" to life.  That said, we've got to keep in mind that this game is still heavily embedded in Alpha.  This review will be based on the Alpha experience I've had, and may not be accurate as time passes.Starting out the game I realized very quickly that I was going to need help.  There was no sign of a tutorial anywhere.  I quickly figured out that if I wanted to get something out of this game I'd have to go do some research.  YouTube to the rescue!  After watching several really good tutorial videos on "getting started", I was quickly able to start moving forward in the world.  That said, I later figured out that the "Campaign" mode has a somewhat vague tutorial built into it.  Meaning, while it did guide me, there were still some things I had to figure out on my own.I'm going to start my actual review with the item editor, since that's a huge plus for this game.  Not watching any tutorials on this, I was able to make a rather nice looking stone sword and shield, but couldn't figure out where they were located in the crafting interface so I could actually craft them in-game.  This was done in "Campaign" mode, so I assume I needed to first learn how to make a "stone hilt" before the weapon would be available to me.  I have to say the item creator is very easy to use and I absolutely love the "mirror" modes while designing.  I also tried to design a stone & wood bike, but I had a few errors in the build (like having no drivable wheel) and couldn't figure out how to fix the problem.I found food to be a very big problem.  The easiest food I found to make required 1 torch to cook each meat.  To make a torch you needed wood (not a problem) and 1 animal fat per torch.  As most animals can easily kick my♥♥♥♥♥ the animal fat was hard to acquire.  Due to this, I kept running out of stamina and my character became rather sluggish.  Even sleeping 12 hours didn't fix my stamina level, although it brought it up a very minor amount.  It left me a little annoied.  I also couldn't figure out how to farm the seeds I had collected from several plants (used for medical supplies).  Perhaps watching more YouTube videos is in order...The worlds, I've got to say, are impressive.  For the most part.  There was a lot of flora and fauna in the world I started out in, but I quickly realized that most of it involved flat props, and not actual 3D plants.  It's kinda like how the creatures were in the original Duke 3D.  Flat, but seemed to always attempt to face your direction so they didn't look flat.  I'm hoping this will be changed as Alpha continues, because it almost ruins the beauty of the landscapes when up-close.  Then again, with the lack of instructions, I could have an option set that makes the flora appear in that manor instead of how it should look.Mining and digging is somewhat similar to other voxel games, like "7 Days to Die" and "Space Engineers", where the ground smoothly deforms instead of cubed removal like how they do in "Minecraft".  Object harvesting is very similar as well.  Trees, for example, must be fully cut down before you actually get resources from them.  That said, at present Trees simply vanish when cut down.  I'd personally like to see some kind of "falling" animation, and the tree vanishing instead as it lands on the ground.Creatures in the game were somewhat interesting.  I'm not exactly sure how creatures come into being, whether it's simply random generation or there is a massive database of them, but I found the ones I ran into to be somewhat strange in appearance.  One looked like the body of a brontosaurus, with the neck of a giraffe, the face of a clown (no word of a lie), and 6 legs.  I turned away from the creature because I deemed it too ugly to kill.  Another seemed to be a very low to the ground creature, hard to see in the flora.  It had 8 legs, a head kinda like an iguana, and a tail like a rat.  I tried to kill it, but my little dagger did virtually nothing.That brings me to combat!  I found it to be a bit unnerving, to say the least.  I couldn’t really tell what was damaging me when a creature attacked.  I couldn’t tell if I was getting clawed, if they were biting me, or if I was taking some kind of area damage.  I couldn’t even tell how much damage I was taking, without staring at my health bar.  There was no visual indicator of damage (No numbers/points appeared), which sometimes left me wondering if I was even hitting the creature.  As their health bars are so compact, unless you do serious (or a lot of) damage it’s hard to tell if the creature’s health is even dropping.Overall I have to say that I’d give the current state of this game a 7/10.  I can’t go any higher because I don’t know if the things that are missing (Tutorial/etc.) will eventually be added.  Right now it seems like a very user unfriendly game.  That said, it’s still early Alpha so I can’t give it too much negativity.  I purchased the game myself, and I’m not regretting that purchase.  We’ll see if that changes as Alpha moves to Beta, and Beta moves to final release…As it stands, if you want to take the risk, then I’d say this game is definitely recommended.  I find the price-point of $24.99 a little high for an Alpha-Version game, but if you consider most finished games sell for something like $60-80 it doesn’t seem too unreasonable.  This game has the formula to be a serious contender in the "sandbox" genre, assuming the dev team stays true to the promises they're making.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is an excelent game, a progession of the minecraft genre combined with the RPG MMO genre.THe graphics, sound and music are well done, and there is plenty of attention to detail, plus as it is still in development, you can add your pennies worth both in the direction it should take and 'bug hunting'.There are 3 main ellements to this game. The explore, mine and craft mode. Build mode, and Create mode.The storyline game is reletivly complete and highly playable, though some of the character behaviour and object template distribution still needs work.You start near your crashed spaceship in a beautiful alien landscape with strange plants. A nearby character gives you a few basic object templates (called scripts in game) which allow you to craft some basic kit (the usual, shovel, axe, sword etc) and a quest.You are free to roam, cut down trees, dig holes and fight creatures for resource gathering. No special table is required for crafting, if you have the script and the raw mats required then you can make the item.As with all these games it is wise to remain relativly close to your starting point and to make some useful kit before ranging too far, and at the same time there is the pull of following the story line, meeting new characters and aquireing that pickaxe upgrade or new laser weapon.In build mode raw materials you have gathered can be used to build with blocks. THere are several shapes (blocks, ramps etc) and free view allowing you to make large and complex architectural structures.In crafting mode you are presented with a separate interface for what is an easy to use 3D object creator. It takes a little playing with to get but is by no means difficult. Here you create items, vehicles and weapons. For some things, like vehicles and weapons there are pre-designed parts (stocks, engines, seats, wheels etc) and already a host of vids and help blogs on the net with ideas and tips for making items.A highly enjoable game with a considerable amount of playability and heeps of potential for budding architects and item crafters, if the developers continue in the current direction, polishing and honing their product this stands to be in the ranks of a classic in due time.If it suffers from one flaw it is that its ambition is immense. Non the less a hightly absorbing enviromnent, playable story line, imaginative and exciting.Highly recommened.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								After playing through the first few missions here is my admittedly barebones initial impressions.  First, the graphics: stunningly beautiful.  Very well done and for the most part, they ran well on my machine.  Character creation: Good beginning.  I know that the developers plan to do more regarding that and look forward to seeing improvement in future updates.  For a game that is still in alpha and only recently released on Steam, pretty good--just don't sit on your laurels guys and gals--I'm looking forward to seeing more.  The early tutorial missions are pretty standard run of the mill--the wood chopping seemed to be a bit off though--some trees I could chop for wood, others very similar I couldn't.  I did like that you could avoid combat in the escort missions--I like the ability to not engage in battle as well as to engage.Had a crash when I first tried to launch the game, but that might have been my fault as I closed out the Steam overlay at the same time.  Tried it again and it launched just fine.  The voice acting was ok--I've heard better, but I've also heard much worse--and in AAA titles.  I do have to ask one thing: Is the developer a Space 1999 fan (The old 70s ITV show)? I ask because of the doctor's name--even though the character by that name in Space 1999 was a pilot and not a doctor.All in all, a promising beginning and I hope this game continues to live up to its promise.

								I simply cannot say enough good things about this game. I've had this game for a while now, and it's absolutely amazing. I'm hard pressed to find another sandbox title like this right now. content:
Posted: March 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is like Farmville (I mean that in the best possible way), but with great graphics, very pretty world. A bit more dangerous than Farmville, you will probably die, but it's all good, that's what revival shots are for. If you are more familiar with Minecraft, I'm not, it's probably a bit like that. A "Voxel" system.You crash land on a planet and start to learn how to live on that planet. The way the textures are done is great, when you are digging a cave, the textures flow well. The minerals you have to collect are easy to spot when you know what you are looking at, the the handheld device helps you find them. I'm enjoying this game.Pros: Well, pretty much everything for a person like me. You have to find things to work with and then make things from that. With the use of the creation system, the trading of isos will flow well, which will release some creative designs, no doubt. Being that this is still an Alpha, I am very impressed. The potential in this game is interesting. Plants. Guns. Cars. Flying cars. Building. Well designed creatures. Nice graphics. A lot of good things to say.Cons: Alpha? A few minor things functionally I'd like to see, but that's how it is with anything, right? Seems well thought out ideas are still possible through suggestions to the developers. Though I can see how too many ideas, all at once, could be an issue for the developers. That's it.I'm liking this game, it's going to end up costing me too many real world hours. Some costs are worth it. Good game for creating cool things, only you will see, but that's half the fun. I think it's worth supporting. After getting the demo Alpha from the creators site, I was sold. Enjoy.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								It's alpha. you'll need to reference the wiki to find out what different items do, how to control the game, and what you ought to be doing.But even with that, it's fun. The item/vehicle/weapon creation system is pretty unique amongst this type of game, and is done reasonably well (a part of me ached to have more Blender-like controls, since modifying existing objects is a bit rough at the moment). Combat is decent, though most of the time I tended to lure monsters to a colony so the colonists killed them for me.After an hour or two of resource collection you won't need to do it again, which is good. It's got a great mining system that smoothly deforms the ground as you mine (it's actually the best implementation of that I've ever seen), but the animation is slow and controlling the camera underground is an exercise unto itself.Building a colony is fun, I appreciate that there's finally a minecrafty game that emphasizes that you're not alone, and allows you to recruit NPCs to work at your colony. There do seem to be some bugs with it, but nothing insurmountable. My biggest gripe is how *small* your colony has to be. It's not feasible to build dwellings and houses for your people, because if you put their beds too far away (read: like 50m away) from the colony center, it won't count towards your colony.Overall, it's definitely rough, but I like where it's going. I'd recommend that if you're uneasy about the "early access" pricetag, that you wait 6 months and give it another go - i expect it'll be more fully-featured at that point. If you want something cool to play *right now*, i'd still go for minecraft or starbound. But this is one to keep an eye on.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 28, 2014
Early Access Review
Everything you want in a video game and moreI've only been playing for a dozen hours but so far I'm immensely impressed by the quality and originality of the game. In recent years (due to the success of MineCraft) the game market has become saturated with sandbox survival games, with few titles delivering a compelling experience. Starting off in story mode, the game plays and functions very much like a normal 3d RPG, the fact that you can alter your surroundings in this world hardly ever registers as its quality is similar to that of any MMORPG of around 2008 (WoW, Guild Wars, etc.). Although the visuals don't (currently) feature HD graphics the world of Maria still manages to be brilliantly beautiful and captivating, relying more on ambiance, flora, lighting, and simplistic symmetry to carve out an idyllic image on various unique landscapes.From the moment you crash land on Maria you will be immersed in the whole world and evolving storyline. The game seamlessly blends sci-fi and medieval elements, making you feel as though you are struggling to survive when beginning with nothing. While you may start off running about with a knife, very soon you will upgrade yourself to a sword and shield, and later laser guns. The combat itself is rather simplistic, point and shoot or stand and stab, but there's enough large monsters to keep you on your toes as you frantically attempt to run between camp on the open plains. (Frankly I'm not sure if the dark forest with lurking wolves or the open tundra with giant warbirds is more terrifying).Of course at the stage of development there are some bugs, but the only game breaking one seems to be an issue with NPC "following" which may disrupt certain quests in the storyline, resulting in a little bit of frustration in trying to escort a glitchy zig-zaging NPC stuck in the ground. Most of the other bugs are pretty minor and I've seen a lot worse in games that put out on the market, so it seems like Pathea is dead set on making a high quality game. While it probably won't see as much success as Minecraft, it'll definetley make a great showing and is a fantastic first game for the publisher.

content:
Posted: August 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								Quite a lot of promise. Lots of tools to craft, materials to mine, and creatures to fight. The creation system is one of the best I've seen in a sandbox game, and the variety of gadgets to play with is outstanding. Just a few missions in, you can use a rope gun and a glider to grapple around like Batman in the Arkham games! And it's still in the Alpha phase!The only downside is that it is not yet optimized. This is a shame because the longer you play, the more fun toys there are to play with, but the slower the game runs, making it harder to enjoy said toys. And it only gets worse underground.I'd be Batmanning it up in the Giant Spider Caves right now if it didn't run at about 13 FPS in my current save file.Still, this is far and away better than your average indie alpha sandbox game. It puts Sir You are Being Hunted, Windforge, StarForge, and Edge of Space to shame. In my opinion, it's worth every penny full price as is, let alone when it's finished.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								It's alpha. you'll need to reference the wiki to find out what different items do, how to control the game, and what you ought to be doing.But even with that, it's fun. The item/vehicle/weapon creation system is pretty unique amongst this type of game, and is done reasonably well (a part of me ached to have more Blender-like controls, since modifying existing objects is a bit rough at the moment). Combat is decent, though most of the time I tended to lure monsters to a colony so the colonists killed them for me.After an hour or two of resource collection you won't need to do it again, which is good. It's got a great mining system that smoothly deforms the ground as you mine (it's actually the best implementation of that I've ever seen), but the animation is slow and controlling the camera underground is an exercise unto itself.Building a colony is fun, I appreciate that there's finally a minecrafty game that emphasizes that you're not alone, and allows you to recruit NPCs to work at your colony. There do seem to be some bugs with it, but nothing insurmountable. My biggest gripe is how *small* your colony has to be. It's not feasible to build dwellings and houses for your people, because if you put their beds too far away (read: like 50m away) from the colony center, it won't count towards your colony.Overall, it's definitely rough, but I like where it's going. I'd recommend that if you're uneasy about the "early access" pricetag, that you wait 6 months and give it another go - i expect it'll be more fully-featured at that point. If you want something cool to play *right now*, i'd still go for minecraft or starbound. But this is one to keep an eye on.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 28, 2014
Early Access Review
Everything you want in a video game and moreI've only been playing for a dozen hours but so far I'm immensely impressed by the quality and originality of the game. In recent years (due to the success of MineCraft) the game market has become saturated with sandbox survival games, with few titles delivering a compelling experience. Starting off in story mode, the game plays and functions very much like a normal 3d RPG, the fact that you can alter your surroundings in this world hardly ever registers as its quality is similar to that of any MMORPG of around 2008 (WoW, Guild Wars, etc.). Although the visuals don't (currently) feature HD graphics the world of Maria still manages to be brilliantly beautiful and captivating, relying more on ambiance, flora, lighting, and simplistic symmetry to carve out an idyllic image on various unique landscapes.From the moment you crash land on Maria you will be immersed in the whole world and evolving storyline. The game seamlessly blends sci-fi and medieval elements, making you feel as though you are struggling to survive when beginning with nothing. While you may start off running about with a knife, very soon you will upgrade yourself to a sword and shield, and later laser guns. The combat itself is rather simplistic, point and shoot or stand and stab, but there's enough large monsters to keep you on your toes as you frantically attempt to run between camp on the open plains. (Frankly I'm not sure if the dark forest with lurking wolves or the open tundra with giant warbirds is more terrifying).Of course at the stage of development there are some bugs, but the only game breaking one seems to be an issue with NPC "following" which may disrupt certain quests in the storyline, resulting in a little bit of frustration in trying to escort a glitchy zig-zaging NPC stuck in the ground. Most of the other bugs are pretty minor and I've seen a lot worse in games that put out on the market, so it seems like Pathea is dead set on making a high quality game. While it probably won't see as much success as Minecraft, it'll definetley make a great showing and is a fantastic first game for the publisher.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								After putting in a full solid day worth of playing I can say this game did not impress me at first.  I found it incomplete having some quests/ dialog voice acted (poorly I might add) and others not at all as well as sketchy UI and graphics issues.  My original intentions were to buy this game for my kids however I'm changing my mind on that due to the games inherent lack of any type of tutorial system.  Some very basic things are outlined for you but most of it is glossed over with little to no detail.  For example you'll have a quest to obtain certain plant types (or kill certain animals).  The most help you'll receive is an extremely tiny picture (literally maybe 50x50 pixels) of what you need to find.  I found myself having to search the online wiki a few times just to get an idea what the heck I was looking for.  Also from what I can gather there is no way to know what you're looking at - mousing over animals or plants doesn't give you the slightest idea what it is you're looking at.  So all you have to go off of is this tiny picture in the mission UI.After a few hours of play though the game did start to grow on me.  It felt like a mix of Minecraft and a RPG.  The graphics are adequate, the game runs fair at best on my i7 Crossfire rig under max settings.  I think this is in part the game does not run in true full screen mode.   I have a triple monitor setup (non eyefinity) and many times (during battle mostly) found myself clicking off the screen thus pushing the game to the background.  In other words in this alleged full screen mode you can still move the mouse beyond the frame of the game.  Also since this is not true full screen it probably plays a role in why crossfire / SLI can't be fully utilized.  Also let me add the game crashed after several hours of play due to a memory leak.If you are running high resolution (1920x1080 for myself) the UI does not scale proportionally making it difficult to see / read.  To my knowledge you can move the UI around which helps you customize and tailor to you needs but you cannot resize any of it.  This is especially true for the mini map.  Devs if you're listening please make the UI scalable / let us resize as we see fit.   I honestly feel the game has huge potential but in its current state needs work.  It definetely feels like an early access game.  If the developers keep an ear to the ground and resolve some of these basic issues this game will have serious legs.As it stands as of today I'd give this title a 76 out of 100.  If the full screen issue was resolved, the game was fully voice acted, and there were better UI and tutorials it would score in the mid to high 80s for me.I'll continue to play it as I feel I've only scratched the surface of what the game has to offer.  I will update this review in the future if need be.update 9/3/2014Ok I completely underestimated this game.  The amount of depth that has gone into the crafting system is impressive.  You go from wooden swords to laser rifles, gatling turrets for base defence - not to mention custom vehicles and aircraft even!  I'm hooked now.  Again because the dev's are doing some things I haven't seen before in a game (which is a good thing) and the lack luster in game help it was slightly frustrating at first.  I watched a few tutorials on YouTube and finally had that "aha" moment with crafting a vehicle.Even in its current Alpha state I'd now give this game a solid 84 out of 100.  I visited the dev website and checked out their forum.  I was very impressed with what appears to be ears to the ground regarding player feedback.  There are pinned posts with the most common suggestions they've looked at and are considering.  As well as status updates galore.  Keep up the good work Pathea!

content:
Posted: July 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								At first, I was mildly excited for a voxel based Minecraft clone, with real combat and a few other advances. To say I have been pleasantly surprised is a gross understatement. I wildly underestimated both the technical expertise of the developers and the coherence and beauty of their vision. BUILDINGTo get a sense of their intent; take Minecraft construction and speed it up a bit, make it take significantly less gathering time, and shrink the scale of any project. In other words, the world of Planet Explorers lends itself to building more things faster, and toward those things feeling like part of a bigger world. (this is not meant as universal praise)TERRAINThe biomes in Planet Explorers (story mode) are gargantuan. You truly feel totally immersed in an alien world, hoofing it across grassy plains. Your character will witness the sun rise and set behind massive mountains that actually sometimes require planning to bypass them to reach your destination quicker or safer! In other words, the terrain achieves relevance AS TERRAIN while at the same time being fully terraformable. WILDLIFEAdding to this are the herds of fauna. In addition to the large number of different types of creatures, there is a huge number of types of AI. You will witness flyers ganging up on prey, troops of monkey creatures fighting off predators, those same predators catching lone monkeys, and many other realistic situations. CRAFTINGSo you take this mix; quick construction, living, breathing fauna, and a gorgeous natural environment, and to it add a heavy layer of crafting. Crafting is very well done, leaning toward recipe trees that make harvesting always fun and profitable, while reducing the actual act of crafting to a minimum (for good or ill). This causes occasional lulls in the frenzied bouts of construction, while allowing one to get back to it after a refreshing harvest period. COMBATCombat is odd. It fufills its function properly; requiring you to watch your back, but not too much, allowing some experimentation and failure without too heavy a penalty, and giving a sense of progress and empowerment over time. The combat itself is fairly clunky at the moment. One's character is required to completely stop moving to perform a combat action (swing, shoot, throw) so it isn't super fast paced action twitch combat. It is however often frenetic and thrilling. My only objection is that healing items are instantly applied and heal for huge amounts, often 70% of your HP. Personally I'd prefer they back off on instant huge heals and, like combat, go for slightly slower action, requiring planning and preparation. SUMMARYOverall, better than I ever imagined I'd get in a game featuring heavy terraforming and construction. To have so many and such varied systems layered atop an already well executed creation game is, frankly, dreamy. PROS & CONS- wildlife view distance is fairly low, leading to some pop-in and unrealistic situations- voxel technology has a ways to go; your creations have a far smaller draw distance than everything else. Again, pop-in.- players who enjoy this type of slower combat don't want to monitor their HP bars for sudden precipitous drops; they want to monitor the RATE of DECREASE of their HP. Conversely, allow movement during combat actions to move toward more action oriented combat.- runs pretty heavily on my SSD, 3+ghz multi-core, decent gfx card system. Not sure if it needs optimization or it's just a heavy game, but either way it wants a beefy system.- texture detail is varied. some are goregous and sharp, others are, hopefully, placeholders.- the humanoid characters look fantastic in terms of animation and graphics. really top notch.- bullets and lasers should really be far faster. - lighting is fantastic both indoors and out. doesn't hog up my FPS, either. (how the hell?!?)- water looks great, needs physics based waves. keeping my fingers crossed.SPECIAL MENTION- billboard grass done right! The view distance on the 3d grass is mind-blowing, and the way they animated it is perfection. Wow.- flowers that bloom at certain times of day! huge boost to immersion- the person behind the "ambience" features in this game is a genius. floating petals and flowery debris is such a subtle but effective addition to the plains biome.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								In a nutshell, and for those that are hesitant or confused on what Planet Explorers truly is, it's a concoction comprised of Starbound and Minecraft, and then what Star Forge was expected to be, but has since fallen short of. If two of the three titles I mentioned ring a bell and you enjoyed them (or in Star Forge's case, didn't and wanted more), you're more than likely going to enjoy this game. Continuing this with this thought, let me explain further, it takes its great exploration and sandbox-like feel from Minecraft, almost heavily with a lot of flare. Explore and you'll find many biomes, fantastic looking creatures that may or may not want to murder you, and land formations and villages and caves waiting to be explored, glided down from, or spelunked. The areas of land are huge, and are quite aesthetically pleasing. Adventure mode will be your friend if you want to explore with a challenge of mobs. From Starbound it takes the great space feel with many different creatures and customization. Even though it technically looks like it would be more similar to minecraft, the building style present in the game feels much more like Starbound, the buildings can be extremely detailed and massive and amazing (I suggest you go check it out on YouTube or just the Steam Community page), and dont worry, if you want to build without threats, theres a mode just for you, no monsters to ruin your time. And from the image of Star Forge, the look and feel of the game and combat (although not quite as… hectic). The generation, the funky mobs, the unexplained, it all fits in very well for the image I had constructed of Star Forge. And to kick it all off, there is a pretty decent (although sometimes grindy RPG style) story to it that explains the occurrences and sends you exploring and hunting and building and saving and protecting the many people of the storyline (which, for better or worse, features almost full voice-acting). I wont spoil anything, but to give an overview of the intro, you are placed in a futuristic setting in which Earth has been browned and polluted, many of the other solar system’s planets and moons colonized and populated, and to branch out further with new hope for the human race as a whole (especially that of Earth’s), you and many many other people were sent to a planet to colonize it and research further. It was scanned and checked before arrival and there shouldn’t be any surprises, however, upon descent, your ship hits something mid-air, evacuation procedures initiate, and off you go to this planet at extreme speeds. Good luck.tl;dr and overall: Pretty good game with a lot of content that is just magnified upon adding more than one person (although no multiplayer Story mode is very disappointing). Crazy builds available for download made by the community, which is more or less balanced in resource cost, makes it even better. Lots of exploration to be had. Good way into the story myself, and I am enjoying it, but sometimes the AI gets a little… wonky. In its current state 7/10 Would recommend, with forewarning of Early-Access. Definitely some bugs (but most can be solved by saving and reloading in Story). Worth every cent.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								Updated Review:After the devs started undertaking an overhall of the game, I tabled it for a while.  I had already completed the story, had my save wiped, and completed it again, so I didn't feel I was missing much.  18 months later, with a0.9 out, i picked it up again... and it's boring.  NOTHING CHANGED!  The view is exactly the same and the graphics don't feel any different.  I looked up a screen shot of my last save, and they look nearly identical, with a few slight differences.  Before the view distances were synced properly, but now the grass can go on forever with no terrain beneath it, making it look like the grass can fly.  There's a weird haze over anything further than ten feet, and the close plants don't appear as vibrant either.  Loading times are longer, and lag spikes are more frequent, but watching my computer performance, not linked to high hardware demands.  So I take it back, it doesn't look the same as before 0.9, it actually looks a bit worse.Sounds now detract from immersion.  Ambient noises like the ocean waves cannot be turned down without turning down sound effects as well.  Voices are hard to hear, and the text font sometimes goes blurry.  The music used to be nice, but after hearing the same thing for hours, it gets monotonous.  The tracks are short and there's little diversity if you're staying in the same area for a long while.  Weapons are put away in the middle of combat because you changed your view angle.  Bows are so weak you might as well be throwing rocks, but you get guns and laser pistols soon enough.  Those also suck until you spend the time upgrading, which I highly recommend.  The turrets are more fond of shooting your own base than any enemy, and there's no quick way to refill them.  Axes won't start hacking at trees unless you have them drawn, not just equiped but drawn.  The interactions to harvest plants are choppy and irritating.  Monsters will despawn while you're still trying to empty their inventory.  Trees magically regain all of their durability if you stop hacking at them for more than a second.The creator tool is still awesome, but at the same time aggravating.  You can create many amazing things, like if you want to spend hours making a sword or carving out a shield, or possibly days on something bigger.  You can change your view angle, and camera locationg, but working intricate designs is extremely difficult.  Even curves are a pain, so most initial designs come out looking like boxes.  I'm not really into moschism, so I just use the scripts or workshop.  I did build my own helicopter though, and let me tell you that's a challenge.  The softest landings damage it, despite tires and iron struts.  That's fine, helicopters are delicate.  So delicate that if you ram into an invisible tree, your creation is dead.  There are also invisible walls marking the edge of the story zone.  No semi-transparent warning, nope, just flaming death.The camps have been changed since I last played though.  Before, the martian camp was decorated with everything they could want or need, which is in line with the story, and I happily stole it all.  Yeah, suck it martians.  I guess the devs didn't like that tactic because now the martians have the same camp, but with skeleton buildings.  No doors, no stairs, no pretty plants, nothing.  And the buildings themselves didn't change to accomodate, they just stripped them bare.The pathing has been improved slightly (very slightly).  Now my followers don't get stuck in a cave, but they do still walk off plateaus, get trapped in rivers ten feet from the beach, get stuck inside buildings, or inside trees, or rarely stuck in an empty field with nothing around.  If you have them assigned to a work station they'll sometimes teleport though, so yay I guess.  Okay, so I ragged on it a bit, but that's mostly due to the devs spending a year getting 0.9 out, and the transition being less than stellar.The price has gone up a bit since I first bought it, but for those that have never played it before, I still recommend the purchase (currently $25).  Yes, it's incomplete and the movements aren't fluid, and mining is slow and painful, but your first dive in will be to an incredible new world with a story that actually makes you curious about why the martians and earthlings hate eachother.  I don't think I ever really found out besides there was a war or something, but I hope there's more (otherwise the backstory sucks and needs some filling out).  Edit:Previous Review, Jun 23, 2014I currently recommend SINGLE PLAYER for this game. While there is a multiplayer function, the lag is terrible on servers of size >6. As for single player story mode.Great game, especially for being in alpha. No major bugs that I found, but at the same time not everything is working yet, which is to be expected. The scanner is the only real pain right now as minerals don't always show up. Combat is as expected, though a first person view would be great for those tighter areas. The story is engaging as I'm trying to solve the internal human problems as well as slowly imagining a history for the alien species. The graphics are amazing, even on low settings, and while there are very different regions, they transition smoothly.

Early Access Review
								Craft/sandbox games are popping up everywhere since the success of Mincecraft.Many of them arn't bad, but are nothing more then "meh" MC clones (I have tried alot of them, and most couldn't keep me interested for very long.)Then there is this beauty.You can mine, chop, and dig, but the landscape isn't "cubed" but adapts dynamically.And ofcourseyou can craft a vast amount of items, build tools, houses, bases, vehicles, etc...But wait ! There is more ! you also have a spore-style editor in-game to craft blueprints for your own custom <any item>.When you are finished building your blueprint (in the game called an "ISO") the game calculates what parts and materials you need to build it, and you can create and use it in-game.Exploration is encouraged, and is much more fun then most MC-style games, because the landscape actually is pretty. You spot alien creatures are ripe for the hunting, but carefull, some might just hunt you. Or work in packs.It looks good, it plays good, and it even has story mode ! (also, adventure, build, ...)If you enjoy Crafting/sandbox/survival games, this one is a must-try.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								Note: At the time of this writing, the game is on Alpha version 0.82.I like that you can download objects from other players from right in the game. I haven't been able to try out the multiplayer yet but I'm looking forward to it. The NPCs in the story do a great job of giving you the scripts you need to build almost everything as long as you do the side quests. It's also nice that I can sell my extra wood and marble to them before buying an item to 'trade' my wood/marble for newer tools.I am enjoying the story missions, when I don't run into a quest stopping bug (Up! Up! Up!). The game has its share of bugs like not locking the mouse into the game window during fullscreen. For dual monitor setups, this means your game will go into window mode every time you click outside of it. I change my setup to single monitor when playing. My game has not crashed at all since the 0.82 update.One of the tricks for a few of the bugs you'll encounter is to save your game often. IF you hit a bug, load up your last save and try again. If you get stuck on a quest ad don't have a save; save, quit, load. I got stuck on a quest to rescue some survivors from a stuck ship and almost gave up after reloading a few times and then it suddenly worked without explanation.tl;dr: It's a great game with a few bugs. The game has great potential. If you like sandbox builders and save often, you'll love this game.
