content:
Posted: July 28, 2014
Early Access Review
Everything you want in a video game and moreI've only been playing for a dozen hours but so far I'm immensely impressed by the quality and originality of the game. In recent years (due to the success of MineCraft) the game market has become saturated with sandbox survival games, with few titles delivering a compelling experience. Starting off in story mode, the game plays and functions very much like a normal 3d RPG, the fact that you can alter your surroundings in this world hardly ever registers as its quality is similar to that of any MMORPG of around 2008 (WoW, Guild Wars, etc.). Although the visuals don't (currently) feature HD graphics the world of Maria still manages to be brilliantly beautiful and captivating, relying more on ambiance, flora, lighting, and simplistic symmetry to carve out an idyllic image on various unique landscapes.From the moment you crash land on Maria you will be immersed in the whole world and evolving storyline. The game seamlessly blends sci-fi and medieval elements, making you feel as though you are struggling to survive when beginning with nothing. While you may start off running about with a knife, very soon you will upgrade yourself to a sword and shield, and later laser guns. The combat itself is rather simplistic, point and shoot or stand and stab, but there's enough large monsters to keep you on your toes as you frantically attempt to run between camp on the open plains. (Frankly I'm not sure if the dark forest with lurking wolves or the open tundra with giant warbirds is more terrifying).Of course at the stage of development there are some bugs, but the only game breaking one seems to be an issue with NPC "following" which may disrupt certain quests in the storyline, resulting in a little bit of frustration in trying to escort a glitchy zig-zaging NPC stuck in the ground. Most of the other bugs are pretty minor and I've seen a lot worse in games that put out on the market, so it seems like Pathea is dead set on making a high quality game. While it probably won't see as much success as Minecraft, it'll definetley make a great showing and is a fantastic first game for the publisher.

content:
Posted: September 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								After putting in a full solid day worth of playing I can say this game did not impress me at first.  I found it incomplete having some quests/ dialog voice acted (poorly I might add) and others not at all as well as sketchy UI and graphics issues.  My original intentions were to buy this game for my kids however I'm changing my mind on that due to the games inherent lack of any type of tutorial system.  Some very basic things are outlined for you but most of it is glossed over with little to no detail.  For example you'll have a quest to obtain certain plant types (or kill certain animals).  The most help you'll receive is an extremely tiny picture (literally maybe 50x50 pixels) of what you need to find.  I found myself having to search the online wiki a few times just to get an idea what the heck I was looking for.  Also from what I can gather there is no way to know what you're looking at - mousing over animals or plants doesn't give you the slightest idea what it is you're looking at.  So all you have to go off of is this tiny picture in the mission UI.After a few hours of play though the game did start to grow on me.  It felt like a mix of Minecraft and a RPG.  The graphics are adequate, the game runs fair at best on my i7 Crossfire rig under max settings.  I think this is in part the game does not run in true full screen mode.   I have a triple monitor setup (non eyefinity) and many times (during battle mostly) found myself clicking off the screen thus pushing the game to the background.  In other words in this alleged full screen mode you can still move the mouse beyond the frame of the game.  Also since this is not true full screen it probably plays a role in why crossfire / SLI can't be fully utilized.  Also let me add the game crashed after several hours of play due to a memory leak.If you are running high resolution (1920x1080 for myself) the UI does not scale proportionally making it difficult to see / read.  To my knowledge you can move the UI around which helps you customize and tailor to you needs but you cannot resize any of it.  This is especially true for the mini map.  Devs if you're listening please make the UI scalable / let us resize as we see fit.   I honestly feel the game has huge potential but in its current state needs work.  It definetely feels like an early access game.  If the developers keep an ear to the ground and resolve some of these basic issues this game will have serious legs.As it stands as of today I'd give this title a 76 out of 100.  If the full screen issue was resolved, the game was fully voice acted, and there were better UI and tutorials it would score in the mid to high 80s for me.I'll continue to play it as I feel I've only scratched the surface of what the game has to offer.  I will update this review in the future if need be.update 9/3/2014Ok I completely underestimated this game.  The amount of depth that has gone into the crafting system is impressive.  You go from wooden swords to laser rifles, gatling turrets for base defence - not to mention custom vehicles and aircraft even!  I'm hooked now.  Again because the dev's are doing some things I haven't seen before in a game (which is a good thing) and the lack luster in game help it was slightly frustrating at first.  I watched a few tutorials on YouTube and finally had that "aha" moment with crafting a vehicle.Even in its current Alpha state I'd now give this game a solid 84 out of 100.  I visited the dev website and checked out their forum.  I was very impressed with what appears to be ears to the ground regarding player feedback.  There are pinned posts with the most common suggestions they've looked at and are considering.  As well as status updates galore.  Keep up the good work Pathea!

content:
Posted: July 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								At first, I was mildly excited for a voxel based Minecraft clone, with real combat and a few other advances. To say I have been pleasantly surprised is a gross understatement. I wildly underestimated both the technical expertise of the developers and the coherence and beauty of their vision. BUILDINGTo get a sense of their intent; take Minecraft construction and speed it up a bit, make it take significantly less gathering time, and shrink the scale of any project. In other words, the world of Planet Explorers lends itself to building more things faster, and toward those things feeling like part of a bigger world. (this is not meant as universal praise)TERRAINThe biomes in Planet Explorers (story mode) are gargantuan. You truly feel totally immersed in an alien world, hoofing it across grassy plains. Your character will witness the sun rise and set behind massive mountains that actually sometimes require planning to bypass them to reach your destination quicker or safer! In other words, the terrain achieves relevance AS TERRAIN while at the same time being fully terraformable. WILDLIFEAdding to this are the herds of fauna. In addition to the large number of different types of creatures, there is a huge number of types of AI. You will witness flyers ganging up on prey, troops of monkey creatures fighting off predators, those same predators catching lone monkeys, and many other realistic situations. CRAFTINGSo you take this mix; quick construction, living, breathing fauna, and a gorgeous natural environment, and to it add a heavy layer of crafting. Crafting is very well done, leaning toward recipe trees that make harvesting always fun and profitable, while reducing the actual act of crafting to a minimum (for good or ill). This causes occasional lulls in the frenzied bouts of construction, while allowing one to get back to it after a refreshing harvest period. COMBATCombat is odd. It fufills its function properly; requiring you to watch your back, but not too much, allowing some experimentation and failure without too heavy a penalty, and giving a sense of progress and empowerment over time. The combat itself is fairly clunky at the moment. One's character is required to completely stop moving to perform a combat action (swing, shoot, throw) so it isn't super fast paced action twitch combat. It is however often frenetic and thrilling. My only objection is that healing items are instantly applied and heal for huge amounts, often 70% of your HP. Personally I'd prefer they back off on instant huge heals and, like combat, go for slightly slower action, requiring planning and preparation. SUMMARYOverall, better than I ever imagined I'd get in a game featuring heavy terraforming and construction. To have so many and such varied systems layered atop an already well executed creation game is, frankly, dreamy. PROS & CONS- wildlife view distance is fairly low, leading to some pop-in and unrealistic situations- voxel technology has a ways to go; your creations have a far smaller draw distance than everything else. Again, pop-in.- players who enjoy this type of slower combat don't want to monitor their HP bars for sudden precipitous drops; they want to monitor the RATE of DECREASE of their HP. Conversely, allow movement during combat actions to move toward more action oriented combat.- runs pretty heavily on my SSD, 3+ghz multi-core, decent gfx card system. Not sure if it needs optimization or it's just a heavy game, but either way it wants a beefy system.- texture detail is varied. some are goregous and sharp, others are, hopefully, placeholders.- the humanoid characters look fantastic in terms of animation and graphics. really top notch.- bullets and lasers should really be far faster. - lighting is fantastic both indoors and out. doesn't hog up my FPS, either. (how the hell?!?)- water looks great, needs physics based waves. keeping my fingers crossed.SPECIAL MENTION- billboard grass done right! The view distance on the 3d grass is mind-blowing, and the way they animated it is perfection. Wow.- flowers that bloom at certain times of day! huge boost to immersion- the person behind the "ambience" features in this game is a genius. floating petals and flowery debris is such a subtle but effective addition to the plains biome.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								In a nutshell, and for those that are hesitant or confused on what Planet Explorers truly is, it's a concoction comprised of Starbound and Minecraft, and then what Star Forge was expected to be, but has since fallen short of. If two of the three titles I mentioned ring a bell and you enjoyed them (or in Star Forge's case, didn't and wanted more), you're more than likely going to enjoy this game. Continuing this with this thought, let me explain further, it takes its great exploration and sandbox-like feel from Minecraft, almost heavily with a lot of flare. Explore and you'll find many biomes, fantastic looking creatures that may or may not want to murder you, and land formations and villages and caves waiting to be explored, glided down from, or spelunked. The areas of land are huge, and are quite aesthetically pleasing. Adventure mode will be your friend if you want to explore with a challenge of mobs. From Starbound it takes the great space feel with many different creatures and customization. Even though it technically looks like it would be more similar to minecraft, the building style present in the game feels much more like Starbound, the buildings can be extremely detailed and massive and amazing (I suggest you go check it out on YouTube or just the Steam Community page), and dont worry, if you want to build without threats, theres a mode just for you, no monsters to ruin your time. And from the image of Star Forge, the look and feel of the game and combat (although not quite as… hectic). The generation, the funky mobs, the unexplained, it all fits in very well for the image I had constructed of Star Forge. And to kick it all off, there is a pretty decent (although sometimes grindy RPG style) story to it that explains the occurrences and sends you exploring and hunting and building and saving and protecting the many people of the storyline (which, for better or worse, features almost full voice-acting). I wont spoil anything, but to give an overview of the intro, you are placed in a futuristic setting in which Earth has been browned and polluted, many of the other solar system’s planets and moons colonized and populated, and to branch out further with new hope for the human race as a whole (especially that of Earth’s), you and many many other people were sent to a planet to colonize it and research further. It was scanned and checked before arrival and there shouldn’t be any surprises, however, upon descent, your ship hits something mid-air, evacuation procedures initiate, and off you go to this planet at extreme speeds. Good luck.tl;dr and overall: Pretty good game with a lot of content that is just magnified upon adding more than one person (although no multiplayer Story mode is very disappointing). Crazy builds available for download made by the community, which is more or less balanced in resource cost, makes it even better. Lots of exploration to be had. Good way into the story myself, and I am enjoying it, but sometimes the AI gets a little… wonky. In its current state 7/10 Would recommend, with forewarning of Early-Access. Definitely some bugs (but most can be solved by saving and reloading in Story). Worth every cent.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								Updated Review:After the devs started undertaking an overhall of the game, I tabled it for a while.  I had already completed the story, had my save wiped, and completed it again, so I didn't feel I was missing much.  18 months later, with a0.9 out, i picked it up again... and it's boring.  NOTHING CHANGED!  The view is exactly the same and the graphics don't feel any different.  I looked up a screen shot of my last save, and they look nearly identical, with a few slight differences.  Before the view distances were synced properly, but now the grass can go on forever with no terrain beneath it, making it look like the grass can fly.  There's a weird haze over anything further than ten feet, and the close plants don't appear as vibrant either.  Loading times are longer, and lag spikes are more frequent, but watching my computer performance, not linked to high hardware demands.  So I take it back, it doesn't look the same as before 0.9, it actually looks a bit worse.Sounds now detract from immersion.  Ambient noises like the ocean waves cannot be turned down without turning down sound effects as well.  Voices are hard to hear, and the text font sometimes goes blurry.  The music used to be nice, but after hearing the same thing for hours, it gets monotonous.  The tracks are short and there's little diversity if you're staying in the same area for a long while.  Weapons are put away in the middle of combat because you changed your view angle.  Bows are so weak you might as well be throwing rocks, but you get guns and laser pistols soon enough.  Those also suck until you spend the time upgrading, which I highly recommend.  The turrets are more fond of shooting your own base than any enemy, and there's no quick way to refill them.  Axes won't start hacking at trees unless you have them drawn, not just equiped but drawn.  The interactions to harvest plants are choppy and irritating.  Monsters will despawn while you're still trying to empty their inventory.  Trees magically regain all of their durability if you stop hacking at them for more than a second.The creator tool is still awesome, but at the same time aggravating.  You can create many amazing things, like if you want to spend hours making a sword or carving out a shield, or possibly days on something bigger.  You can change your view angle, and camera locationg, but working intricate designs is extremely difficult.  Even curves are a pain, so most initial designs come out looking like boxes.  I'm not really into moschism, so I just use the scripts or workshop.  I did build my own helicopter though, and let me tell you that's a challenge.  The softest landings damage it, despite tires and iron struts.  That's fine, helicopters are delicate.  So delicate that if you ram into an invisible tree, your creation is dead.  There are also invisible walls marking the edge of the story zone.  No semi-transparent warning, nope, just flaming death.The camps have been changed since I last played though.  Before, the martian camp was decorated with everything they could want or need, which is in line with the story, and I happily stole it all.  Yeah, suck it martians.  I guess the devs didn't like that tactic because now the martians have the same camp, but with skeleton buildings.  No doors, no stairs, no pretty plants, nothing.  And the buildings themselves didn't change to accomodate, they just stripped them bare.The pathing has been improved slightly (very slightly).  Now my followers don't get stuck in a cave, but they do still walk off plateaus, get trapped in rivers ten feet from the beach, get stuck inside buildings, or inside trees, or rarely stuck in an empty field with nothing around.  If you have them assigned to a work station they'll sometimes teleport though, so yay I guess.  Okay, so I ragged on it a bit, but that's mostly due to the devs spending a year getting 0.9 out, and the transition being less than stellar.The price has gone up a bit since I first bought it, but for those that have never played it before, I still recommend the purchase (currently $25).  Yes, it's incomplete and the movements aren't fluid, and mining is slow and painful, but your first dive in will be to an incredible new world with a story that actually makes you curious about why the martians and earthlings hate eachother.  I don't think I ever really found out besides there was a war or something, but I hope there's more (otherwise the backstory sucks and needs some filling out).  Edit:Previous Review, Jun 23, 2014I currently recommend SINGLE PLAYER for this game. While there is a multiplayer function, the lag is terrible on servers of size >6. As for single player story mode.Great game, especially for being in alpha. No major bugs that I found, but at the same time not everything is working yet, which is to be expected. The scanner is the only real pain right now as minerals don't always show up. Combat is as expected, though a first person view would be great for those tighter areas. The story is engaging as I'm trying to solve the internal human problems as well as slowly imagining a history for the alien species. The graphics are amazing, even on low settings, and while there are very different regions, they transition smoothly.

content:
Posted: July 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								At first, I was mildly excited for a voxel based Minecraft clone, with real combat and a few other advances. To say I have been pleasantly surprised is a gross understatement. I wildly underestimated both the technical expertise of the developers and the coherence and beauty of their vision. BUILDINGTo get a sense of their intent; take Minecraft construction and speed it up a bit, make it take significantly less gathering time, and shrink the scale of any project. In other words, the world of Planet Explorers lends itself to building more things faster, and toward those things feeling like part of a bigger world. (this is not meant as universal praise)TERRAINThe biomes in Planet Explorers (story mode) are gargantuan. You truly feel totally immersed in an alien world, hoofing it across grassy plains. Your character will witness the sun rise and set behind massive mountains that actually sometimes require planning to bypass them to reach your destination quicker or safer! In other words, the terrain achieves relevance AS TERRAIN while at the same time being fully terraformable. WILDLIFEAdding to this are the herds of fauna. In addition to the large number of different types of creatures, there is a huge number of types of AI. You will witness flyers ganging up on prey, troops of monkey creatures fighting off predators, those same predators catching lone monkeys, and many other realistic situations. CRAFTINGSo you take this mix; quick construction, living, breathing fauna, and a gorgeous natural environment, and to it add a heavy layer of crafting. Crafting is very well done, leaning toward recipe trees that make harvesting always fun and profitable, while reducing the actual act of crafting to a minimum (for good or ill). This causes occasional lulls in the frenzied bouts of construction, while allowing one to get back to it after a refreshing harvest period. COMBATCombat is odd. It fufills its function properly; requiring you to watch your back, but not too much, allowing some experimentation and failure without too heavy a penalty, and giving a sense of progress and empowerment over time. The combat itself is fairly clunky at the moment. One's character is required to completely stop moving to perform a combat action (swing, shoot, throw) so it isn't super fast paced action twitch combat. It is however often frenetic and thrilling. My only objection is that healing items are instantly applied and heal for huge amounts, often 70% of your HP. Personally I'd prefer they back off on instant huge heals and, like combat, go for slightly slower action, requiring planning and preparation. SUMMARYOverall, better than I ever imagined I'd get in a game featuring heavy terraforming and construction. To have so many and such varied systems layered atop an already well executed creation game is, frankly, dreamy. PROS & CONS- wildlife view distance is fairly low, leading to some pop-in and unrealistic situations- voxel technology has a ways to go; your creations have a far smaller draw distance than everything else. Again, pop-in.- players who enjoy this type of slower combat don't want to monitor their HP bars for sudden precipitous drops; they want to monitor the RATE of DECREASE of their HP. Conversely, allow movement during combat actions to move toward more action oriented combat.- runs pretty heavily on my SSD, 3+ghz multi-core, decent gfx card system. Not sure if it needs optimization or it's just a heavy game, but either way it wants a beefy system.- texture detail is varied. some are goregous and sharp, others are, hopefully, placeholders.- the humanoid characters look fantastic in terms of animation and graphics. really top notch.- bullets and lasers should really be far faster. - lighting is fantastic both indoors and out. doesn't hog up my FPS, either. (how the hell?!?)- water looks great, needs physics based waves. keeping my fingers crossed.SPECIAL MENTION- billboard grass done right! The view distance on the 3d grass is mind-blowing, and the way they animated it is perfection. Wow.- flowers that bloom at certain times of day! huge boost to immersion- the person behind the "ambience" features in this game is a genius. floating petals and flowery debris is such a subtle but effective addition to the plains biome.

content:

Early Access Review
								SPOILER: This review is small and pretty opinionated. It is  not  a comprehensive review on all features and I  have not  explored every feature availble to the game currently, just most of them. I likely will not explore too much more of the game and it's features but, as I support this game, I will closely monitor it's patches and development.PROS: For the most part, in it's current state, this game is very fun to play.-Multiplayer; being able to gather materials faster and more efficiently to be able to build helicopter gunships for decimating alien encampments is far too much fun. Honestly, after my experience playing the game with my friends, the fun we had was almost criminal.-Hunting; when it comes to hunting these large-scale dinosaur-like creatures, this game really shines. Especially when you have access to better gear so you don't have to rely on hit and run tactics to lure the beasts towards your substantially better equipped AI.-Crafting; holy♥♥♥♥♥♥ Being able to craft  real  technology is amazing. No more of that unnecessarily complicated, unreasonably restrictive redstone fluffy flutter from Minecraft.  Real Technology  with a  real impact  on gameplay and progression. The list of available recipes is gigantic and, at first, very overwhelming. But it makes the game really something to behold.-Vehicles; worth. Do you like strapping lazer canons and missile silos onto a poorly made car with thrusters and calling it a helicopter gunship? I do. Do you like using that very same vehicle to wreak mayhem and destruction on those god damned Aliens that endlessly spawn from their camps? I do.CONS: That's right, you knew we would get to this part as soon as you saw the word "pros". And to a great degree of sadness, this list is much larger than the other one. So much larger, it's hard to pick a good starting place.-Multiplayer; ♥♥♥♥ing port-forwarding. Everyone's least favorite chore. I  literally  have friends who would rather pay me their hard-earned, broke college student funds than do their own port-forwarding. Ironically, even I don't like doing it. It's bizarre; it's complicated and simple at the same time. Usually you just go to your router's browser page at 192.168.1.1 and follow some simple directions to get the port forwarded. Combine that with some firewall exceptions and you've got yourself an open port for some multiplayer madness. Assuming it actually works. Which, most of the time, is the problem. There's almost  never  a layman's solution to port-forwarding without buying a program to forward the ports for you. You can't just strap in and forward the ports without having to learn the arbitrary process first, it rapidly gets you very involved and educated on how to do it like a professional through a mind-numbing few hours of trial and error. And unless you do it the mythical  right way,  which is different per router, you'll find that before long your ports are closed again. tl;dr port forwarding for multiplayer is a bad solution, but a cheap one. Invest a little in better multiplayer and watch the crowds eat up your game.-Hunting; oh boy. Want to hunt something that can't  wreck  you like it's name was Ralph? Really boring and offers almost nothing you'll need to build decent survival gear or buy it. Want to hunt something that  actually  gives a worthwhile supply of necessary materials like animal skins and fat or isn't just plain boring to fight? Well be prepared to overly rely on your AI or multiplayer comrades because otherwise it will kill you and♥♥♥♥♥♥your corpse into the ocean. For most of the entire game, it's usually a far safer idea to simply avoid almost everything and mine for materials in vast quantities to be able to emerge from the earth as the most powerful entity on the planet. But then the game is boring because nothing provides a challenge anymore.-Crafting; bore chore. As excellent as the crafting system of this game is at delivering impacful technology that feels as good as it performs... Actually crafting it is obnoxiously boring. It's all about making excessively vast quantities of little materials to be able to make smaller and smaller quantities of larger and larger materials until you have everything you need. The only redeeming feature here is that you can produce things in bulk, which you'll quite often rely on because otherwise you'll have to make  all  of the necessary materials over and over again until you no longer need to make whatever oddity you're crafting to begin with. It takes such a long time to make anything worthwhile or important,  especially  the various vehicles in the game.-Vehicles; I didn't sign up for this. The vehicle creation menu/functionality is a very frustrating feature of the game. Especially for those like myself that aren't very creative-minded and  SWEAT  when presented that much crafting freedom. As much as I like the freedom offered in the feature, you need to at least present some guidelines or most players will just be lost in the age old question of "Where the ♥♥♥♥ do I even start?" Let's not even get that much into the controls of the vehicle crafting feature because all that needs to be said is prepare to rely on the undo function heavily as you constantly mutter "I didn't want to do that". Or the arbitrary fact that you have to go into a separate menu just to assign wheels for steering. Last, the fukitol cherry on top, multiplayer additional seating is present in the game but currently not functioning properly or even with any sense of purpose. But I imagine that last bit will be fixed soon.-Gathering; so many problems. Wood gathering? Takes too damn long if you want to get any worthwhile amount of wood that is determined seemingly  at ♥♥♥♥ing random  based on the size of the tree you're chopping down. Mineral gathering? Prepare to scour every inch of the planet trying to even  find  these materials. They're arbitrarily hard to locate; but I guess that's not so bad when you can mine them in the thousands if you're willing to spend the time doing it once you actually find a vein. Underwater/Oceanic gathering? Unfortunately necessary for the later parts of the game. To make matters worse, to build a boat for easy/safe underwater/oceanic gathering you need oil/petroleum. To get this, you need a boat to be able to safely traverse the waters without getting immediately killed by a dino-shark-demon. I'm sure you see the cycle here.-Voxels/Vertices/Whatever; the last, but greatest con.  NEVER IN THIS GAME IS IT WORTH TO MINE WITHOUT AT LEAST A COPPER PICKAXE  You'll mine voxels/vertices/whatever so finely that creating a mine to work in that isn't game breaking or safe to actually stand in is next to impossible unless you're really diligent and have the time on hand to actually do it. Copper pickaxes are one of the first pickaxes that actually mine larger voxels/vertices so you can make flat surfaces for mining much more easily. But again, this is mainly only achievable if you are willing to take the time necessary to actually do that. And based on the reactions of my friends in multiplayer, nobody wants  that  job.That would be about it. I really enjoy this game, but it just needs a few fixes and gameplay changes. But this should be expected as it is still in alpha. Would I recommend this game? Definitely. Would I recommend this game while it's still in alpha? Yeah, I still would. But there are definitely some fixes that need to happen for the dev team to maximize player enjoyment. If you're sitting on the fence with this game, allow me to say that it's well worth it if you're willing to look past some clear flaws and just have fun playing what works really well. Either way, keep a close eye on the game's development and patches for improvements and fixes; I know I will be.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								I have played mostly the story mode, using the building functionality to weave in a little creativity, but I have yet to play this a la Minecraft. But I really, really like the game! The story is interesting, the world is immersive, and it's just plain cool. It's a very well done game. However, it's by all means still in Beta.My complaints:-Some of the missions require walking back and forth across the (very large) map, with fast traveling not an option when you have a follower. I dislike that, it's a waste of time. Enabling followers to fast travel with you would fix this, and I'm confident they'll do that before the final version.-The storyline gets implayable at a certain point. I hit a wall where a bug disallowed the game from recognizing one action as complete, and it couldn't progress the story. Obviously, these will be handled before a full release, so it's not fair to say the game is bad when it's simply (and admittedly) incomplete, but I thought it was nonetheless worth mentioning in my review.-Gathering resources to go through stuff you use in regular gameplay gets a little tedious. You can buy resources from certain NPCs, but the quantities available are small and the prices high. Building your own stuff is a nice part of the game, but gathering resources for an hour just to restock on bullets is annoying. Again, I expect they may improve this before the final release.My praises:-I really like the way combat is done, the way you can focus on it or not. There's a fair amount of combat to be done, but I just made automatic turrets, carry them in my inventory, and let them take care of whatever it is while I just keep clear. That way, combat for me is just making sure I've got enough turrets and ammo in my inventory for whatever I expect to fight.-The RPG and the sandbox elements work together really nicely.-The opening quests do a good job explaining how the game works. It did take me a minute to figure out what buttons to press, but once I got that down the explanations were helpful without being annoying.All in all, I think this game will be one of my favorites once it's done. The RPG gameplay seems to only be 60% done, whereas the builder gameplay seems to be 95% up and running. So depending on your gameplay preferences, you may prefer to wait it out until it's a little more complete. I personally chose to put it aside and plan to revisit it when it's complete, since I was more focused on the RPG gameplay, but I definitely recommend it either way.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								Surprisingly advanced for an Early Release. The story line is believable, voice acted, and complex. The world (I've only seen the first 2 areas of 7 I'm guessting), is massive, varied, and not without dangers. No, you won't get chewed up by any hostile mob, but when starting out you'll have to run. and mine, and do the quests. Later you'll be able to get on your self-built motorbike, and *try* to outrun a dangerous enemy you found deep in the forst. Will you be able to dodge the trees? Will he? After many many disappointments in its genre, I'm fully willing to say that this is a massive success in the in the Voxel / Survival / Crafting / Single player game, even well beyond anything else out there. My only negative is the ingame music, which sounds like children's lullabies to my ears... But it's easy enough to mute it through the settings (which are completely implemented), and run VLC in the background. Average performance usage of system while running Planet Explorers AND a 720P movie in VLC:CPU 38%RAM usage around 5 GB of 16GB. Nvidia GTX 760, no cooling (not even a fan). Resolution 1920x1080 on main screen running Planet ExplorersResolution 1280x720 on second monitor, playing the Terra Nova Series on 720p. --------------I recommend this game for children, especially those of all ages. This is absolutely playable for children in multiplayer with their parents, and it would be a great experience for them.You can build, and you can dig to find oreyou can do quests to find out more.Sneak around to see beautiful creaturesand learn what could become of own features. ----FANTASTIC GAME!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								TLDR; Recommended, glad I purchased it.It's really addictive. Check the other reviews and, even on the bad ones, notice how many HOURS people log playing this game! I'm ONLY at 13 hours.It reminds me a bit of Uninhabited Planet Survive[en.wikipedia.org] which was a fun show. If you liked the show you'll probably like the game, although I'm certain they have totally unrelated origins.I like exploring, building, and sometimes even following the story.The difficulty isn't very linear, which isn't a bad thing. In the real world you can walk into a forest and attack a rabbit or a bear side by side, but.. which one is more difficult? That's what happens here, too. And smaller isn't always less of a challenge either, likewise some big guys are pushovers. Could make it harder, actually.I haven't had much luck with Online play, though. It works sort-of, but my latency was measured in minutes so it wasn't really playable. Could be just me, but hey, it's a product in development.Solo play is rock solid, the graphics are awesome. There's tons to build and do already. While the game is solid and hasn't crashed on me, as other reviewers point out, it has some bugs. You may never experience them, but they're in there.

content:
Posted: March 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								   If the amount of time i spent playing this game from the moment i  installed it is any indication, i'd give this game even in it's current alpha state 5 stars.   The combination of Minecraft style crafting system with an RPSesque story mode to give the rest of it some kind of point creates an experience that makes you actually CARE about delving into the depths for that last chunk of iron or coal. the addition of an integrated creation system that allows you to make anything from a stool to a house to a racetrack and a vehicle to race on it in multiplayer, as well as weapons and almost anything else you can imagine while still being constrained by the resources and items you've gathered in-game makes for an incredibly immersive world experience.   i got sucked in and played 33 hours the first two days i had this game. i am almost dreading the final release as the alphas scope only encompasses a small portion of the world so far an approximate 40km square area that i have as yet not found the end of.   support this game, get the alpha!

No more of that unnecessarily complicated, unreasonably restrictive redstone fluffy flutter from Minecraft.  Real Technology  with a  real impact  on gameplay and progression. The list of available recipes is gigantic and, at first, very overwhelming. But it makes the game really something to behold.-Vehicles; worth. Do you like strapping lazer canons and missile silos onto a poorly made car with thrusters and calling it a helicopter gunship? I do. Do you like using that very same vehicle to wreak mayhem and destruction on those god damned Aliens that endlessly spawn from their camps? I do.CONS: That's right, you knew we would get to this part as soon as you saw the word "pros". And to a great degree of sadness, this list is much larger than the other one. So much larger, it's hard to pick a good starting place.-Multiplayer; ♥♥♥♥ing port-forwarding. Everyone's least favorite chore. I  literally  have friends who would rather pay me their hard-earned, broke college student funds than do their own port-forwarding. Ironically, even I don't like doing it. It's bizarre; it's complicated and simple at the same time. Usually you just go to your router's browser page at 192.168.1.1 and follow some simple directions to get the port forwarded. Combine that with some firewall exceptions and you've got yourself an open port for some multiplayer madness. Assuming it actually works. Which, most of the time, is the problem. There's almost  never  a layman's solution to port-forwarding without buying a program to forward the ports for you. You can't just strap in and forward the ports without having to learn the arbitrary process first, it rapidly gets you very involved and educated on how to do it like a professional through a mind-numbing few hours of trial and error. And unless you do it the mythical  right way,  which is different per router, you'll find that before long your ports are closed again. tl;dr port forwarding for multiplayer is a bad solution, but a cheap one. Invest a little in better multiplayer and watch the crowds eat up your game.-Hunting; oh boy. Want to hunt something that can't  wreck  you like it's name was Ralph? Really boring and offers almost nothing you'll need to build decent survival gear or buy it. Want to hunt something that  actually  gives a worthwhile supply of necessary materials like animal skins and fat or isn't just plain boring to fight? Well be prepared to overly rely on your AI or multiplayer comrades because otherwise it will kill you and♥♥♥♥♥♥your corpse into the ocean. For most of the entire game, it's usually a far safer idea to simply avoid almost everything and mine for materials in vast quantities to be able to emerge from the earth as the most powerful entity on the planet. But then the game is boring because nothing provides a challenge anymore.-Crafting; bore chore. As excellent as the crafting system of this game is at delivering impacful technology that feels as good as it performs... Actually crafting it is obnoxiously boring. It's all about making excessively vast quantities of little materials to be able to make smaller and smaller quantities of larger and larger materials until you have everything you need. The only redeeming feature here is that you can produce things in bulk, which you'll quite often rely on because otherwise you'll have to make  all  of the necessary materials over and over again until you no longer need to make whatever oddity you're crafting to begin with. It takes such a long time to make anything worthwhile or important,  especially  the various vehicles in the game.-Vehicles; I didn't sign up for this. The vehicle creation menu/functionality is a very frustrating feature of the game. Especially for those like myself that aren't very creative-minded and  SWEAT  when presented that much crafting freedom. As much as I like the freedom offered in the feature, you need to at least present some guidelines or most players will just be lost in the age old question of "Where the ♥♥♥♥ do I even start?" Let's not even get that much into the controls of the vehicle crafting feature because all that needs to be said is prepare to rely on the undo function heavily as you constantly mutter "I didn't want to do that". Or the arbitrary fact that you have to go into a separate menu just to assign wheels for steering. Last, the fukitol cherry on top, multiplayer additional seating is present in the game but currently not functioning properly or even with any sense of purpose. But I imagine that last bit will be fixed soon.-Gathering; so many problems. Wood gathering? Takes too damn long if you want to get any worthwhile amount of wood that is determined seemingly  at ♥♥♥♥ing random  based on the size of the tree you're chopping down. Mineral gathering? Prepare to scour every inch of the planet trying to even  find  these materials. They're arbitrarily hard to locate; but I guess that's not so bad when you can mine them in the thousands if you're willing to spend the time doing it once you actually find a vein. Underwater/Oceanic gathering? Unfortunately necessary for the later parts of the game. To make matters worse, to build a boat for easy/safe underwater/oceanic gathering you need oil/petroleum. To get this, you need a boat to be able to safely traverse the waters without getting immediately killed by a dino-shark-demon. I'm sure you see the cycle here.-Voxels/Vertices/Whatever; the last, but greatest con.  NEVER IN THIS GAME IS IT WORTH TO MINE WITHOUT AT LEAST A COPPER PICKAXE  You'll mine voxels/vertices/whatever so finely that creating a mine to work in that isn't game breaking or safe to actually stand in is next to impossible unless you're really diligent and have the time on hand to actually do it. Copper pickaxes are one of the first pickaxes that actually mine larger voxels/vertices so you can make flat surfaces for mining much more easily. But again, this is mainly only achievable if you are willing to take the time necessary to actually do that. And based on the reactions of my friends in multiplayer, nobody wants  that  job.That would be about it. I really enjoy this game, but it just needs a few fixes and gameplay changes. But this should be expected as it is still in alpha. Would I recommend this game? Definitely. Would I recommend this game while it's still in alpha? Yeah, I still would. But there are definitely some fixes that need to happen for the dev team to maximize player enjoyment. If you're sitting on the fence with this game, allow me to say that it's well worth it if you're willing to look past some clear flaws and just have fun playing what works really well. Either way, keep a close eye on the game's development and patches for improvements and fixes; I know I will be.

content:
Posted: November 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								(Updated March 2016) No, Planet Explorers is NOT dead. It is still being updated with large substancial patches and currently aims to be released in 2016. Yes, it took a long time since PE reached Greenlight in 2013, but game development simply does take a lot of work and time, especially when we're talking about such a large and refined (optionally) quest-driven sandbox-game with so many - nearly endless - possibilities (change the beautiful world with it's different biomes to your liking, craft all kinds of stuff from tiny decorations over equipment and vehicles to large buildings with the creation-system, keep up your comfort-level to stay healthy, hunt the naturally behaving awesome-looking animals, defeat giant boss-mobs for quests, defend NPCs and your own fully powered-up SF-colony with turrets, discover weird alien structures, scan and dig for ore, play the mainquest or try free survival on procedurally generated worlds...Too many players being impatient and completely ignorant of all warnings about what Early Access means have created a bad reputation for the whole Early Access system. Sadly Planet Explorers is one of these games that have been slandered because of EA and some players even said that Panthea had "abandoned" this game, while in reality they have regularly kept on updating it. In my personal opinion, Planet Explorers - even in its current state - is already the best of all games I've ever played. * it features large, beautiful, variated and imaginative non-blocky 3D-game-worlds with different biomes and interesting flora. There's one predefined gameworld for the "campaign"-mode, plus procedurally generated worlds that players can create with different settings to choose from* even better - these worlds are populated by fantastic creatures (six-leggers like in Martian Dreams!) endemic to each biome, behaving "naturally" - meaning herds sticking together while roaming the regions, carnivores hunting herbivores in packs, animals sleeping at night, flocks of birds flying off when getting close, etc. - plus giant boss-mobs too (you juast have to love the whale-like Ostrov Sharks)* on the "campaign"-world you can discover awesomely weird looking alien ruins, dams, highways, great walls and camps with hand-made alien buildings* in the campaign you can interact with a decent number of unique NPCs, each with their own personality and background-story - and of course quests, ranging from subquests (fetch me x herbs) to really large main quests (defend a camp with turrets, defeat giant robots/mobs, learn to grow plants, establish a whole colony with different powered structures)* by now you can play PE both (or alternating) in first person and third person mode btw.* you can build extremely large structures like bridges, walls and buildings etremely quickly directly into the game-world with the smootest gameplay mechanics ever. You can save your structures and then copy more of them into the world too - however logically you will need to collect all the necessary materials beforehand* additional to that PE features an awesome creation-system that allows you to create, save, copy and share tons of stuff - all of the equipmant and vehicles you can build will even have certain stats and such will have a gameplay-impact within the game, depending on the materials it's been made of and it's shape. You can design every kind of object from tiny to large, from simple tableware and decoration items to furniture and streetlamps to large buildings.* with the usual ingame-crafting-menu (replicator) you can craft a wide range of pre-set equipment and other stuff too without having to design it specifically. Most of these have a really nice and unique SF-look* after prospecting/scanning for ores you can dig an infinite number of mineshafts and tunnels into the world. Well, you can even shovel away whole mountains if you're in the mood to do so* building defensive walls and different turrets will help you with battling larger enemies, and you will need this after setting up a colony, because there will be irregular invasions, during which native creatures will try to get to the power core of the colony to shut it down* you cannot only craft many different vehicles (also flying ones) in the creator-menu, but you can even build a refined monorail-system across your gameworld. You can dive into deep underwater caves with or without a wetsuit and you can fly by using a wingsuit or later on also jetpacks* the campaign-mode features an RPG-like story with quests and a down-to-earth background-story that is unveiled bit by bit. While it might not be to everyone's taste, I personally like it* there's a minecraft-like free creative/builder-mode with an infinite amount of all materials to freely build and craft with* the third game-mode is a survival-mode for adventurers, featuring an optional skill-unlock-system on randomly generated game-worlds sprinkled with NPC- and alien-settlements and optional small quests - set your own goals there without the RPG-story taking you by the hand* you can ask NPCs to live in your colony and defend the colony (together with your turrets) both in campaign-mode and also in adventure-mode* lately a comfort-level and illnesses have been added to the game, together with medicine to cure your character that you can brew or buy from NPCs. So now it is advised to sleep regularly and not to get soaked in the rain for too long. And digging for seeds (that you can plant) in animal dung might have an affect on your character's health as well...* there are multiplayer-options too now, so you can invite other players to your server or join them on theirs* the performance on my 64bit Windows 7 prof. is totally alright, no problems with the FPS here. I very, very rarely experienced freezes or quest-bugs. No problems with the sound and also nearly none with the graphics. However the game might not run as smoothly on every existing system, and I still experienced frequent crashes after playing for a longer while in early 2016.

content:

Early Access Review
								Amazing game! This one is definitely worth the money, despite being Alpha. The animals are fierce, but not OP, and i never felt like i was put in a situation that was unfair. Usually if i died, it was because i was a dumbass. The weapons are fun, and i had a blast killing everything i came across for fun, which is coincidentally also why i usually died. The story is really good, and kept me interested, which is rare for Open world games when it comes to me. My only complaint is that occasionally AI will forget the revive juice that you give them, and end up not using it when they get knocked out. I would also like them to add some system to differentiate predators and prey, and possibly a better way to find certain animals, as i haven't been able to find one animal for a sidequest.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								Lot's of PotentialThis game has been on my wishlist for a while and I finally picked it up during the Summer Sale. I have been playing in Story mode, so that it was this review will focus on.The graphics are 50/50 for me on this game. On the one hand, you have beautiful ditant scenery that you can actually go to. On the other hand, you'll walk over plants that are flat and seem to follow the camera. The character graphics are fine, but nothing that wowed me.The gameplay is similar to Minecraft (a favorite game of mine) in that you will need to dig for ores and then craft items out of them. The mining aspect is interesteing in that sometimes you'll have to dig out an area. You can't just mine straight through. [Also, if you want to go spelunking, make sure you have a rope gun. Otherwise, if you don't dig a gently sloping tunnel down to the caves, you'll need to dig one to get out or fast travel.]The quest system is what you would expect. Go to an NPC. Talk. Get quest. Complete quest. Get reward. The one area that I would like to see improvement in is the Designing area. The item designer is not user friendly and can be difficult to figure out. The one thing that I think would vastly improve this area is the ability to select and move pieces that you have placed. Additionally, it would be nice for there to be some basic designs available to the player already. Not everyone wants to go in and design a car.If you get the chance, pick this game up. It's got a great foundation of gameplay and should only get better.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 18, 2014
Early Access Review
								SPOILER: This review is small and pretty opinionated. It is  not  a comprehensive review on all features and I  have not  explored every feature availble to the game currently, just most of them. I likely will not explore too much more of the game and it's features but, as I support this game, I will closely monitor it's patches and development.PROS: For the most part, in it's current state, this game is very fun to play.-Multiplayer; being able to gather materials faster and more efficiently to be able to build helicopter gunships for decimating alien encampments is far too much fun. Honestly, after my experience playing the game with my friends, the fun we had was almost criminal.-Hunting; when it comes to hunting these large-scale dinosaur-like creatures, this game really shines. Especially when you have access to better gear so you don't have to rely on hit and run tactics to lure the beasts towards your substantially better equipped AI.-Crafting; holy♥♥♥♥♥♥ Being able to craft  real  technology is amazing. No more of that unnecessarily complicated, unreasonably restrictive redstone fluffy flutter from Minecraft.  Real Technology  with a  real impact  on gameplay and progression. The list of available recipes is gigantic and, at first, very overwhelming. But it makes the game really something to behold.-Vehicles; worth. Do you like strapping lazer canons and missile silos onto a poorly made car with thrusters and calling it a helicopter gunship? I do. Do you like using that very same vehicle to wreak mayhem and destruction on those god damned Aliens that endlessly spawn from their camps? I do.CONS: That's right, you knew we would get to this part as soon as you saw the word "pros". And to a great degree of sadness, this list is much larger than the other one. So much larger, it's hard to pick a good starting place.-Multiplayer; ♥♥♥♥ing port-forwarding. Everyone's least favorite chore. I  literally  have friends who would rather pay me their hard-earned, broke college student funds than do their own port-forwarding. Ironically, even I don't like doing it. It's bizarre; it's complicated and simple at the same time. Usually you just go to your router's browser page at 192.168.1.1 and follow some simple directions to get the port forwarded. Combine that with some firewall exceptions and you've got yourself an open port for some multiplayer madness. Assuming it actually works. Which, most of the time, is the problem. There's almost  never  a layman's solution to port-forwarding without buying a program to forward the ports for you. You can't just strap in and forward the ports without having to learn the arbitrary process first, it rapidly gets you very involved and educated on how to do it like a professional through a mind-numbing few hours of trial and error. And unless you do it the mythical  right way,  which is different per router, you'll find that before long your ports are closed again. tl;dr port forwarding for multiplayer is a bad solution, but a cheap one. Invest a little in better multiplayer and watch the crowds eat up your game.-Hunting; oh boy. Want to hunt something that can't  wreck  you like it's name was Ralph? Really boring and offers almost nothing you'll need to build decent survival gear or buy it. Want to hunt something that  actually  gives a worthwhile supply of necessary materials like animal skins and fat or isn't just plain boring to fight? Well be prepared to overly rely on your AI or multiplayer comrades because otherwise it will kill you and♥♥♥♥♥♥your corpse into the ocean. For most of the entire game, it's usually a far safer idea to simply avoid almost everything and mine for materials in vast quantities to be able to emerge from the earth as the most powerful entity on the planet. But then the game is boring because nothing provides a challenge anymore.-Crafting; bore chore. As excellent as the crafting system of this game is at delivering impacful technology that feels as good as it performs... Actually crafting it is obnoxiously boring. It's all about making excessively vast quantities of little materials to be able to make smaller and smaller quantities of larger and larger materials until you have everything you need. The only redeeming feature here is that you can produce things in bulk, which you'll quite often rely on because otherwise you'll have to make  all  of the necessary materials over and over again until you no longer need to make whatever oddity you're crafting to begin with. It takes such a long time to make anything worthwhile or important,  especially  the various vehicles in the game.-Vehicles; I didn't sign up for this. The vehicle creation menu/functionality is a very frustrating feature of the game. Especially for those like myself that aren't very creative-minded and  SWEAT  when presented that much crafting freedom. As much as I like the freedom offered in the feature, you need to at least present some guidelines or most players will just be lost in the age old question of "Where the ♥♥♥♥ do I even start?" Let's not even get that much into the controls of the vehicle crafting feature because all that needs to be said is prepare to rely on the undo function heavily as you constantly mutter "I didn't want to do that". Or the arbitrary fact that you have to go into a separate menu just to assign wheels for steering. Last, the fukitol cherry on top, multiplayer additional seating is present in the game but currently not functioning properly or even with any sense of purpose. But I imagine that last bit will be fixed soon.-Gathering; so many problems. Wood gathering? Takes too damn long if you want to get any worthwhile amount of wood that is determined seemingly  at ♥♥♥♥ing random  based on the size of the tree you're chopping down. Mineral gathering? Prepare to scour every inch of the planet trying to even  find  these materials. They're arbitrarily hard to locate; but I guess that's not so bad when you can mine them in the thousands if you're willing to spend the time doing it once you actually find a vein. Underwater/Oceanic gathering? Unfortunately necessary for the later parts of the game. To make matters worse, to build a boat for easy/safe underwater/oceanic gathering you need oil/petroleum. To get this, you need a boat to be able to safely traverse the waters without getting immediately killed by a dino-shark-demon. I'm sure you see the cycle here.-Voxels/Vertices/Whatever; the last, but greatest con.  NEVER IN THIS GAME IS IT WORTH TO MINE WITHOUT AT LEAST A COPPER PICKAXE  You'll mine voxels/vertices/whatever so finely that creating a mine to work in that isn't game breaking or safe to actually stand in is next to impossible unless you're really diligent and have the time on hand to actually do it. Copper pickaxes are one of the first pickaxes that actually mine larger voxels/vertices so you can make flat surfaces for mining much more easily. But again, this is mainly only achievable if you are willing to take the time necessary to actually do that. And based on the reactions of my friends in multiplayer, nobody wants  that  job.That would be about it. I really enjoy this game, but it just needs a few fixes and gameplay changes. But this should be expected as it is still in alpha. Would I recommend this game? Definitely. Would I recommend this game while it's still in alpha? Yeah, I still would. But there are definitely some fixes that need to happen for the dev team to maximize player enjoyment. If you're sitting on the fence with this game, allow me to say that it's well worth it if you're willing to look past some clear flaws and just have fun playing what works really well. Either way, keep a close eye on the game's development and patches for improvements and fixes; I know I will be.

												This game has so many things going for it. Runs great, looks great, interesting life forms, story mode, adventure mode, collecting resources, build structures, vehicles, armor and weapons. Create your own colony, farm build hunt explore. Single player, optional multiplayer, pvp if you want or play co-op and start a community. Huge map of different biomes and Workshop, the people over at Pathea Games put heart and soul into this game and you really can't go wrong with this one.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								Great game with amazing features. They continue to update with new content and fixes that satisfy! This game will put you right in the middle of an alien planet and let you explore with virtually no limits. Create amazing items and immediately play using them in-game. You can also export items and share with friends very easily as well! Hands down the best thing about this game is the true sandbox nature, backed up by amazing visuals and an extremely powerful creation system. The don't just toss you into an sandbox, they give you the toys to truely enjoy the experience!

content:

Early Access Review
								I adore this game, there is so much to do, particularly with crafting, and exploring the world is always interesting thanks to the wide variety of animal and plant species. Seeing some of the animals travelling in herds, and watching different species battle it out is amusing. Then you also have the huge scary alien tribes!This game really has some of the most in depth crafting for weapons, items and vehicles allowing you to make them your own and totally unique.I paid full price for this and have no regrets!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								BUY THIS GAME, if you like open-world sandboxes, you will not regret this purchase. There is so much to do... It's a bit overwhelming at first, but once you know what you're doing, this is a very enjoyable game. It's kind of like if minecraft was built in a realistic world... and in space. Or maybe a 3D starbound. Just as addictive, at least.I've had a few problems with broken missions and inventory items dissapearing, but it's rare and will likely be fixed very soon. With that said, for an alpha, this game is phenominal! This is one of those games that comes along and changes the tide of every game made after it.I've played about 10 hours logged and 5 offline, So far I've only built my first vehicle, encountered my first sentient aliens, and my first gigantic monster-bug. 15 hours and I've only scratched the surface of this game... I see a LOT of replay value here, especially with mods.... I'm very excited to see the finished product!

content:
Posted: January 23, 2015
Early Access Review
								First of, this is a great game. Just the jetpack-glider combination alone, is almost worth the buying price (use the jetpack to gain altitude, then glide around the game world. lots of fun).Furthermore there's an interesting storyline, and it's a builder game, where you can build all kinds of things, even your own colony, and inhabit it with npcs, that you can recruit from the various story areas.Also, the game is still in development, so from time to time, new content become available, such as more main story, more gameworld, more build or npc options, and so on.But there lies the biggest issue, from my perspective: The updates.As each time a new update comes around, your savegame is no longer working.The devs usually give out a savegame, so you can continue the storyline, from where it stopped last, which is okey, but it's just not good enough.If you spend 40+ hours playing the game and building stuff, having to start all over each time there is an update, gets old REAL fast.And for me, that is the deal breaker. Until savegames can be used from update to update, I will not recommend this game.

content:
Posted: October 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								A few things that give this game alot of potential as a open world sandbox game is;ability to design your own weapons, items, and vehicles. This is what sets the game from all other games that allows for crafting and open world sandbox. You can choose to build the ingame items or upload/create items of your own. decent crafting treedevs are coming out with a world editor that allows you build your own world and populate it as you see fitthe storyline questing is decent enough to get you started into the game before you choose to go into adventure mode and strike it out on your own. But  what I dislike about the game;very awkward User interface. it takes more clicks than it needs to craft or perform certain functions such as scanning. The devs said they are working on this and hope to release a new UI in the next month or two so we'll seeLacks a true vibrant multiplayer environment. Most of the multiplayer servers are empty. And even if you do find a decent one, you can be subject to griefing because there is currently no way to protect your stuffThere's no sense of challenge or purpose. I get that it's open world sandbox and the only agenda is the one you set.However it feels boring just logging on and killing creatures and building stuff. The game needs more conflict.documentation needsdespite special effects such as damage dealing effects are non existent and needs to be improved upon. Other than a little green bar at the top, you don't know if you're doing damage. Positioning around the NPC can feel awkward as well.Aside from building stuff and killing creatures, there just isn't enough motivation or purpose to playing the game.  It needs more players on the multiplayer servers as well. I will review this game in another month or two and update my review.

number of helpful: 10 of 22 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 14, 2016
												BEWARE - If you will potentially want a refund (which you likely will) If you attempt to play multiplayer, despitethe fact you more than likely wont get it working port forwarding or no, when you quit the game leaves a process running in the background and continues to count as being played by steam. So even though we only loaded it up and tried to get a multiplayer server going a couple times; it sais we have played for over 15 hours each making a refund more difficult. Make sure when you quit you lookin task manager for the process and end it manually.Now my experience from playing on my mates account (what drove me to misguidedly buy it in the first place)1. The item creation is really cool, played around making my friend items on his computer, however being able to make your own items is the only good part of this game and once you see the game itself, even this is lacking.1.1 the item creater looks extensive however it is missing core parts which effectively mean that items you will find in game will be better than what you can create anyway. eg, you can get 2H melee weapons in game, you cannot make 2H weapons in the creator. You can get many different 1H hilts in game, but can only use the first 3 low tier ones in creator.this put a massive dampening on the only good part of the game.2. Graphically it is uninspiring and extremely dated, which I can excuse if the gameplay was fun.3. The gameplay is not fun, starting out doing the very first quest in adventure mode and I got swamped by about 8 NPC humanaoid enemies which hit like trucks and you basically cannot damage. Sure, you can kite them around for half an hour shooting them with your rubberbands (bow) or hitting them with your wet tissue (sword), but it isnt fun.3.1 combat is woeful, despite being able to double tap to dodge, dodging does exactly nothing for you.4. Audio, The sound is quite calming and nice which is a good thing and likely designed to stop you raging at game mechanics.5. Multiplayer, the "multiplayer" basically does not work,we tried creating a private server with port forwarding set correctly and noone could see the servers, regardless of which one of us set it up. You can create it via a proxy server based god knows where and then 90% of the game mechanics are broken by the latency. eg die (because the first NPC you talk to in town spawns about 15 high level mobs with firearmswhile you haven't even made a wood bow) and then cannot respawn, BUT you can drive your nameplate around ....6. As mentioned, when attempting to make a server it created a background process which does not exit when you exit the game, racking up hours and preventing an easy refund.I have a suspiscion that this is intentional because there is no way in hell this game is in release standard.7. The environments are boring and extremely vast nothingnesses, games liek 7 days  to Die also have this but the environment still feels alive and dangerous somehow, not so here.8. The AI, should just be renamed A.I could go on, however in summary; I had quite a bit of enjoyment creating items to use in game which I could copy from my mates computer easily enough, however that is the end of the fun in this game, there are soooooo many bugs, features that down work and lack luster mechanics that it is obvious this game is still in alpha or EA.It is definately not in release. or worth ~$30 asking price, to expand - this is I tihnk the only comment I have made on steam in the many years and games (even ones I regret buying) that i have asked for a refund.

Early Access Review
								I'll keep this short and sweet:Pros: Voxel editor is funMost of everything works as intendedDigging/mining works as it should usually.Excellent sandboxCons:Very silly/shallow storyMain map is based around story modeDevs are putting out about two updates a year, maybeUpdate is generally related to the story that nobody cares aboutVoxel editor is clunky interface wiseImporting textures is too much of a hassle, same with making custom voxels for the editor.Custom weapons are nrealy impossible to make equal to the pre-made weapons w/o looking like silly blocksMelee combat is clunkyAll guns feel like watergunsHaving too many voxel objects (10+) makes the game lag/crash even on a high end rigTL;DR Devs are focused on the wrong stuff, when they care about the game at all. content:
Posted: August 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								You know, I don't understand the comments haters seem to possess for this game. I mean, because it is playable, you seem to think that it has to be finished on your own time. It is in ALPHA not BETA. When a game is in the ALPHA stage, it is still being designed and littered with bugs and glitches. Some games can take much longer than the designers plan to be completed, you know. Plus, the game designers have their own lives to deal with, along with this game's development. I mean, they could have family members dying, or their wives could be pregnant, etc. Considering that this game has sooooo much potential, you guys should be more patient. On a more positive note, I would give this game a 9.5/10. It has a ton of potential and, once all the bugs and glitches are fixed, I truly believe this game could become one of the best games of the year. I mean, it is games like this that make the video gaming industry so successful. So please, please guys, be more patient. I feel as though I can almost guarantee that the wait will be worth it. P.S. One of the few problems that I have with this game is the name of the planet. "Maria" is such a boring name and I feel that it could be better. And if the name was chosen because the designers couldn't come up with a better name, I bet I could think up some good names. Just a thought...

content:
Posted: April 15, 2014
Early Access Review
								There is a lot of potential in this game.However at this point in development, it's just that, potential.The only reason why this game is getting a "Not recommended" is because the timing on everything is off. From the amount of time it takes to gather resources to the animations of the creatures and NPCs.I could see myself making some really cool creations in this game, but I can't bring myself to spend the hours to gather all the resources needed to do so. So I then tried the build mode that gives you infinite resources from the very begining and found myself getting bored of building because it took too long to do a simple flat diagonal bridge over a small crevasse (something like 20+ minutes).The way how the building works is really cool with the options to expand on the XYZ planes before placing the blocks you want. However, due to the constraints of the camera, I found I could only build outwards/upwards so far before I would have to reposition myself for a better view of what I was working on. The process than became: build a little then move a little and repeat until done.I'd like to see different sized blocks that I could place as the current size can be VERY small when working on anything larger than a small shack (and even then I found myself doubling up on the wall thickness because I felt a single block wide wall looked like a couple sheets of plywood stuck together).As far as the story section goes, my only comment would be to do away with the voice acting as sometimes it seems out of place, like the voice actors were distracted while reading their lines. Otherwise I found the missions/quests to be very entertaining and fun.Overall, I'd say pass on this for now and wait for the game to become more fleshed out. It's interesting and visually impressive AND the terra forming is superb. But, the amount of time you spend on creating anything will try your patience as it can feel like you're building because you HAVE to and not because you want to as well as you'll feel like you're fighting the camera to get anything done.

The questline is horribly bugged, and it is unlikely that you will be able to get though it at all.The game is in more of an alpha state. There are major parts of the game that are currently not accesible.

content:
Posted: September 20, 2014
Early Access Review
								First off, id like to note that this game has incredible potential, i can only imagine how amazing it would be at a complete stage(thats assuming it will ever get there). One of my main frustrations is the lack of attention the devs are putting into their own creation. Yes i payed to support development, and whether or not they continue is their choice. Im proud of my decision because i feel that im supporting a great idea. I was pitched a game that promises much and does deliver, however here are some things that i do find detremintal to gameplay.-Poor Mechanincs-Lack of Unique Enviroments-Terrible Ai programming(hopefully in the future i can interact with all intelligent npcs in several ways, creating a real feeling rpg. I want my actions to be reflected in game. It would be great if aliens did more than just walk a few steps and then unintelligently try to persue me(they usually just get stuck behind rocks)-MULTIPLAYER DEV. For the love of god, this game deserves more multiplayer development. I want to explore the world with friends and random players, i want a unique world that punishes you and rewards you because of your actions (such as players who become anarchists or those who follow colony rules) which brings me to another topic-Colonies: You place a few tents and one or two bungalows and call that a colony? Please make this feel like a sci-fiction game. Give me colony police, factions, trade markets, anything to make it feel like an "RPG". Create background stories for the multiplayer, smart AI that can use vehicles and scout the land. Add small cities, maybe even a nice military branch you could join in which you raise in rank and can possibly explore other worlds(Just and idea).Make it feel like a Sci-fi game-Lack of replayablity: The survival mode is really needs some work, it doesnt feel difficult, especially when i have to find other aliens to have some action. A few random search parties and attacks on my locations would be nice. Destroyable buildings would be nice as well, as once i hide i am pretty much safe for the rest of eternity.-fix the vehicles: Poor mechanics, easily damaged.Overall the game provided entertainment but not for long. I quickly realized that planet explorers was unfortunately boring and not worth the money i payed. I hoped that my money would atleast bring me great updates to enjoy, but the developers  are making slow and low quality updates that dont really make the game any different.So, i do not recommend you buy this game for any reason other than for a future version that gives more playable content. In other words, dont buy it in its current state.
